ECR applauds the prioritization of EU accession conditional on rule-of-law reforms, which directly counters foreign interference from Russia and China as emphasized in multiple interventions.  
ECR proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly name state actors enabling cross-border corruption networks, addressing concerns about omitted accountability for Belgrade/Moscow-linked influence operations.  
ECR fully promotes visa liberalization for Kosovo as a stability measure, recognizing it strengthens pro-European forces against organized crime structures opposing EU integration.  
ECR strongly approves the call for synchronized sanctions with US counterparts, reinforcing their stance against kleptocratic elites financing anti-democratic propaganda in the region.

ID slightly promotes the crime-fighting objectives but rejects tying EU integration prospects to anti-mafia effectiveness, citing ideological overreach.  
ID requests revising the issue to address the unmentioned Balkan migration route and Turkish influence enabling trafficking networks.  
ID opposes using Kosovo recognition as an implicit precondition, arguing it politicizes law enforcement cooperation.  
ID demands evidence that Montenegro's EU accession reduced organized crime before endorsing further expansionist conditionality.  
ID insists on prioritizing Croatia's border security over abstract judicial reforms to disrupt cross-border drug trafficking.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about organized crime and corruption in the Western Balkans, emphasizing their detrimental impact on regional stability, EU integration, and citizen trust in democracy. It highlighted structural issues linking organized crime to state institutions, money laundering, tax evasion, and a grey economy exceeding 30% of regional GDP, alongside challenges like judicial inefficiency, political impunity, and COVID-19-related fraud. The resolution stressed the need for robust judicial reforms, enhanced cross-border cooperation with EU agencies (Europol, Eurojust, Frontex), and alignment with international conventions on corruption, cybercrime, and firearms trafficking. It noted €64 million allocated under IPA II for anti-crime projects, urging Western Balkan states to improve asset recovery, protect whistleblowers, and prioritize prosecuting high-profile criminals. The Parliament called for visa liberalization for Kosovo, stronger civil society and media roles, and EU alignment with US sanctions targeting corruption. It advocated regional cooperation through initiatives like SEESAC and the Berlin Process, while urging improved data collection, gender-sensitive policies, and measures against human trafficking, drug smuggling, and illicit arms trade. The resolution linked EU accession progress to tangible reforms, warning that IPA III funding could be suspended for regression in rule of law, and emphasized addressing disinformation, foreign interference, and socio-economic vulnerabilities fueling crime.

title: EU Association Agreement with the Republic of Moldova: REPORT on the implementation of the EU Association Agreement with the Republic of Moldova | A9-0143/2022 | European Parliament
background: Following Moldova's 2020-2021 elections establishing pro-reform leadership, sustained EU engagement under the 2014 Association Agreement/DCFTA, pandemic recovery challenges, energy dependence, and unresolved Transnistria tensions amid geopolitical pressures, the Parliament will discuss progress in implementing EU-Moldova cooperation frameworks and reform priorities to advance political association and economic integration.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions granting candidate status to Moldova, aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to European integration and the pro-EU government's reform agenda.  
EPP applauds Moldova's exemplary humanitarian response to Ukrainian refugees as a demonstration of shared European values and solidarity.  
EPP urges the immediate creation of a dedicated EU support group for Moldova to mirror Ukraine's assistance framework, enhancing technical coordination for accession preparations.  
EPP endorses accelerated judicial reforms to combat systemic corruption, emphasizing this as critical for fulfilling Moldova's European aspirations.  
EPP emphasizes Moldova's linguistic and historical ties to the EU, asserting that Romanian-language recognition strengthens its rightful place in the European family.

SD strongly sanctions Moldova’s EU membership application and commends its solidarity in hosting Ukrainian refugees, aligning with S&D’s commitment to European integration and humanitarian values. The EU should accelerate disbursement of the €600 million Economic Recovery Plan to stabilize Moldova’s economy amid external pressures.  

SD approves the emphasis on judicial and administrative reforms, which align with S&D’s priority to strengthen rule-of-law institutions. A minor enhancement is proposed: deepen sectoral cooperation under the ‘Associated Trio’ framework to accelerate Moldova’s legal harmonization with EU standards.  

SD applauds Moldova’s democratic progress and anti-corruption efforts, reflecting S&D’s values of transparency. The issue effectively advances these goals but could enhance youth engagement by expanding access to DiscoverEU to foster pro-European identity.  

SD endorses energy diversification as critical to reducing Moldova’s dependency on Russian supplies, proposing enhanced EU support for renewable energy infrastructure and cross-border connectivity projects as a strategic enhancement.  

SD emphasizes the urgency of granting Moldova candidate status to galvanize reforms, aligning perfectly with S&D’s vision of an inclusive EU. The issue’s call for swift assessment of Moldova’s readiness should be prioritized given the post-invasion security context.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the EU’s commitment to Moldova’s European integration and territorial integrity, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to Eastern Partnership solidarity amid external aggression.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on judicial and anti-corruption reforms, which effectively advance their priority of institutional resilience against state capture and hybrid threats.  
GREEN_EFA proposes accelerating the disbursement of pledged €600 million recovery funds to address Moldova’s urgent energy and humanitarian needs, enhancing the issue’s impact.  
GREEN_EFA totally endorses granting Moldova EU candidate status without delay, reflecting the clear democratic choice of its citizens and the government’s reform trajectory.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses deepening sectoral cooperation through the ‘Associated Trio’ initiative, urging expanded technical assistance to strengthen Moldova’s administrative decentralization.

ECR strongly promotes Moldova’s European aspirations, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to fostering sovereignty and democratic resilience among EU partner nations.  
ECR approves the emphasis on judicial reforms as critical to combating systemic corruption, effectively advancing ECR’s priority of institutional accountability and rule of law.  
ECR proposes strengthening parliamentary oversight mechanisms for EU financial assistance to ensure transparent utilization of the €600 million recovery plan as an enhancement opportunity.  
ECR applauds Moldova’s solidarity with Ukraine amid Russian aggression, reflecting shared values of regional stability central to ECR’s foreign policy principles.  
ECR endorses the ‘Associated Trio’ initiative as a strategic framework for deeper sectoral integration, consistent with ECR’s vision of pragmatic EU partnerships.

ID rejects the issue's endorsement of Moldova's EU integration, citing Moldova's high corruption levels (ranked 105th) as firmly condemning with ID's stance against admitting states failing core governance criteria.  
The proposal overlooks critical financial implications, with ID emphasizing that Moldova's status as a long-term net recipient would impose unsustainable burdens on EU economies like Germany.  
ID opposes the issue's geopolitical approach, warning that Transnistria's potential accession referendum creates unacceptable risks of direct confrontation with Russia.  
The issue's reform conditionality fails to address ID's core principle that EU membership must be strictly reserved for nations meeting all Copenhagen criteria without exception.  
ID condemns the disregard for taxpayer interests, asserting that allocating €150 million in assistance prioritizes political aspirations over fiscal responsibility.

GUE_NGL rejects the reliance on conditional loans and free-market solutions as inadequate to address Moldova’s social collapse, completely disputeing with their demand for non-repayable solidarity funding.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s emphasis on structural resilience through austerity-aligned reforms, which overlook youth emigration drivers like poverty and wage stagnation.  
The proposal’s focus on sectoral cooperation via the ‘Associated Trio’ framework contradicts GUE_NGL’s anti-neoliberal critique of EU Eastern Partnership conditionalities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of binding commitments for energy price stabilization, failing Moldovan citizens during the 2021 gas crisis exacerbated by EU energy market rules.  
This approach perpetuates dependency through debt instruments rather than addressing systemic inequality, directly opposing GUE_NGL’s manifesto principle of unconditional crisis support.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and acknowledged progress in implementing the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, emphasizing the need for accelerated reforms to combat systemic corruption and fulfill Moldova’s European aspirations following the 2020 presidential and 2021 parliamentary elections, which established a pro-EU government. It highlighted the EU’s €600 million Economic Recovery Plan to address COVID-19 impacts and drive structural resilience, alongside a proposed €150 million Macro-Financial Assistance package in January 2022. The resolution stressed the urgency of judicial and administrative reforms to strengthen institutions, alongside EU support for Moldova’s Parliament through a November 2021 Memorandum of Understanding. It welcomed the ‘Associated Trio’ initiative (Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine) endorsed at the December 2021 Eastern Partnership summit, urging deeper sectoral cooperation. The EU reaffirmed support for Moldova’s territorial integrity amid external pressures, notably during the 2021 gas crisis, and called for progress on resolving the Transnistria conflict via the 5+2 format. Overall, the resolution underscored the EU’s commitment to bolstering Moldova’s reforms, sovereignty, and integration through sustained political, financial, and technical assistance.

title: COVID-19 pandemic in Latin America: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the COVID-19 pandemic in Latin America | RC-B9-0239/2021 | European Parliament
background: Latin America, experiencing pre-existing high inequality and fragile health systems, faced disproportionate COVID-19 mortality rates, economic strain, and exacerbated social disparities, worsened by limited vaccine access and governance challenges. The Parliament will discuss EU-Latin America cooperation on pandemic response, equitable recovery, and multilateral strategies to address health and socio-economic crises in the region.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely approves the issue’s emphasis on equitable vaccine distribution through COVAX, perfectly aligning with its commitment to global solidarity and justice, while proposing enhanced production mechanisms to address critical shortfalls in dose allocation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the condemnation of politically motivated discrimination in vaccination programs, urging immediate transparency measures to ensure aid reaches all populations without ideological barriers.  
EPP fully supports the call for debt relief and IMF support as essential to Latin America’s recovery, reflecting its longstanding advocacy for sustainable development aligned with SDG frameworks.  
EPP endorses the issue’s focus on combating disinformation through initiatives like PortalCheck.org, reinforcing its principle of evidence-based policymaking and scientific cooperation.  
EPP fully backs the proposed transnational health institute, viewing it as a strategic extension of EU-Latin American partnership models and a vital step toward pandemic preparedness.

SD completely upholds the issue’s emphasis on vaccine equity through COVAX, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to global health justice and its advocacy for vaccines as a universal public good.  
SD perfectly aligns with the condemnation of Bolsonaro’s pandemic mismanagement, underscoring the issue’s urgency in addressing leadership-driven public health failures that endanger regional and global security.  
SD completely upholds the call for debt relief and IMF reforms, recognizing this as critical to advancing SD’s priorities on economic justice and sustainable recovery in line with the 2030 Agenda.  
SD strongly agrees the issue’s focus on combating disinformation through initiatives like PortalCheck.org, reflecting SD’s longstanding work against pseudoscience and digital threats to democracy.  
SD completely upholds enhanced EU-LAC health cooperation, including the proposed transnational institute, as it directly advances SD’s vision of multilateralism and equitable access to healthcare for marginalized communities.

GREEN_EFA totally agrees the issue's prioritization of gender justice, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to combat femicide and systemic violence against women across Latin America.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for vaccine equity through COVAX and proposes strengthening Article 12 by explicitly mandating EU support for patent waivers to scale up regional production capacities.  
The issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority of transnational health justice by linking debt relief to pandemic recovery, mirroring their advocacy for IMF reform tied to SDG-aligned investments.  
GREEN_EFA highlights enhancement opportunities in Section 3(b), urging amplified funding for grassroots women’s shelters and digital rights initiatives like PortalCheck to counter gender-based disinformation.  
This aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s longstanding commitment to decolonial solidarity, particularly in condemning state repression against indigenous communities while expanding vaccine access to informal economies.

ECR strongly promotes the issue’s urgent mobilization of EU-Latin American solidarity, aligning with their commitment to countering Chinese and Russian geopolitical influence through strategic partnerships.  
ECR approves the emphasis on vaccine equity via COVAX but proposes amending the text to explicitly link disinformation combat efforts to countering foreign state actors, strengthening PortalCheck.org’s mandate against adversarial narratives.  
The issue effectively advances ECR’s priority of context-sensitive aid by deploying the EU Civil Protection Mechanism to address critical gaps in regions like Amazonia and Patagonia, distinct from European urban challenges.  
ECR endorses debt relief and IMF reforms as essential to prevent economic dependency, consistent with their advocacy for sovereign development free from external coercion.  
ECR highlights the necessity of assistance framed as collaboration rather than condescension, strongly promoteing measures that respect Latin American nations’ autonomy while addressing systemic inequalities.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to mandate patent waivers as completely disputeing with their demand for public health over pharmaceutical profits.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EU's reliance on COVAX distribution without addressing intellectual property barriers, which perpetuates vaccine apartheid in Latin America.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's silence on corporate profiteering, noting that 70 billion euros to shareholders starkly contradicts pandemic solidarity claims.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's inconsistency with anti-capitalist principles by prioritizing market mechanisms over compulsory licensing for vaccine production.  
GUE_NGL asserts that the omission of patent abolition constitutes complicity in preventable deaths, aligning with Big Pharma interests rather than human rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the devastating impact of COVID-19 on Latin America and the Caribbean, which accounts for 8.4% of the global population but over 20% of pandemic-related deaths. It highlighted the region’s exacerbated inequalities, with poverty rising by 22 million people and extreme poverty by 8 million in 2020, alongside heightened gender-based violence and disproportionate effects on indigenous communities due to inadequate healthcare access. The resolution urged enhanced EU-Latin American cooperation, including deploying the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, boosting vaccine production and equitable distribution through COVAX (which allocated 27 million doses to 31 countries in the region), and increasing the EU’s financial support to COVAX to €1 billion. It called for protecting human rights, ensuring pandemic measures are proportional, and condemning repression and disinformation campaigns. The Parliament emphasized the need for debt relief, IMF Special Drawing Rights issuance, and inclusive recovery strategies aligned with the SDGs, while advocating for urgent vaccine access for marginalized groups, including migrants and informal workers. It also stressed combating pseudoscience and online disinformation, supporting initiatives like PortalCheck.org, and fostering regional health cooperation, including a proposed transnational institute for infectious diseases.

title: Blasphemy laws in Pakistan, in particular the case Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the blasphemy laws in Pakistan, in particular the case of Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel | RC-B9-0254/2021 | European Parliament
background: Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, in place since 1986, have faced criticism for enabling persecution of religious minorities and misuse through false accusations, exemplified by the 2014 death sentence of Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel despite evidence inconsistencies. The Parliament will discuss the laws’ human rights implications and Pakistan’s compliance with international obligations under EU trade agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally upholds the issue’s condemnation of Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, perfectly aligning with their commitment to global religious freedom and human rights.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for immediate release of Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel, emphasizing the systemic judicial flaws and lack of evidence in their case.  
EPP fundamentally upholds the call to repeal Sections 295-B and 295-C of Pakistan’s Penal Code, reflecting their longstanding opposition to laws enabling persecution of minorities.  
EPP strongly sanctions linking Pakistan’s GSP+ trade benefits to human rights compliance, urging the EU to enforce accountability for systemic abuses.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on protecting legal professionals and journalists, aligning with their advocacy for rule of law and free expression in authoritarian contexts.

SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s unequivocal condemnation of Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, perfectly aligning with SD’s foundational commitment to religious freedom and human dignity.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to abolish capital punishment in all cases, particularly for Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel, whose illiteracy and lack of evidence exemplify systemic injustice.  
The issue effectively advances SD’s priority of protecting minorities by urging Pakistan to dismantle laws enabling mob violence against Christians, Ahmadis, and other marginalized groups.  
SD fully supports leveraging the EU’s GSP+ trade mechanism to pressure Pakistan into compliance with international human rights standards, as outlined in the issue’s strategic linkage.  
This aligns perfectly with SD’s advocacy for judicial integrity, endorsing the call to end coerced confessions and ensure medical care for detainees like Shafqat Emmanuel, a paraplegic denied basic rights.

ECR completely promotes the issue’s demand for the immediate release of Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to defending religious freedom and opposing unjust persecution.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the call to leverage the EU’s GSP+ trade mechanism to pressure Pakistan, emphasizing the urgency of linking economic benefits to concrete human rights reforms.  
ECR completely promotes the condemnation of Pakistan’s systemic misuse of blasphemy laws, which directly advances ECR’s priority of protecting minorities from state-sanctioned violence and legal abuse.  
ECR perfectly supports the issue’s focus on combating anti-French rhetoric linked to blasphemy disputes, reflecting ECR’s stance against extremism that threatens global religious coexistence.  
ECR completely promotes the demand to abolish the death penalty in blasphemy cases, in perfect harmony with ECR’s unwavering opposition to capital punishment and advocacy for judicial integrity.

ID fully agrees the issue’s condemnation of Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, perfectly aligning with ID’s commitment to defending religious minorities and secular governance.  
ID emphasizes the urgent need to halt EU financial aid to Pakistan, reinforcing the issue’s demand to review GSP+ eligibility until blasphemy laws are repealed.  
ID highlights the disproportionate targeting of Christians and Ahmadis under these laws, mirroring the issue’s call to address systemic persecution and forced conversions.  
ID applauds the focus on Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel’s case, urging immediate medical care and release as a critical step to counter judicial abuse.  
ID condemns Pakistan’s anti-French rhetoric linked to blasphemy disputes, aligning with the issue’s demand to protect diplomatic missions and combat extremism.

resolution: The European Parliament raised serious concerns over Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, which since 1986 have imposed severe penalties, including death or life imprisonment for blasphemy against Islam, fueling widespread abuse, mob violence, and persecution of religious minorities such as Christians, Ahmadis, Hindus, and Shi’a Muslims. Highlighting the case of Shagufta Kausar and Shafqat Emmanuel—a Christian couple sentenced to death in 2014 based on unsubstantiated allegations of sending blasphemous text messages, despite their illiteracy and lack of evidence—the resolution condemned systemic flaws in judicial processes, including coerced confessions, prolonged pretrial detention, and inadequate medical care for detainees. It noted over 1,855 blasphemy charges filed between 1987 and February 2021, with 2020 marking the highest number of accusations, exacerbating a climate of fear, forced conversions, and violence against minorities. The resolution urged Pakistan to repeal blasphemy laws (specifically Penal Code sections 295-B and C), ensure fair trials, protect legal professionals and witnesses, and address rampant misuse of these laws for personal vendettas or political gain. It called for an immediate review of Pakistan’s eligibility for the EU’s GSP+ trade benefits, citing non-compliance with human rights obligations, and pressed for international pressure to safeguard religious freedoms, end forced conversions, and halt the death penalty. The Parliament also condemned anti-French rhetoric in Pakistan linked to blasphemy disputes and urged enhanced protections for journalists, activists, and vulnerable groups facing online and offline attacks. Finally, it reiterated opposition to capital punishment and demanded urgent medical care and release for unjustly detained individuals, emphasizing the laws’ incompatibility with Pakistan’s constitutional and international human rights commitments.

title: Bolivia and the arrest of former President Jeanine Añez and other officials: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Bolivia and the arrest of former President Jeanine Añez and other officials | RC-B9-0244/2021 | European Parliament
background: Following Bolivia’s 2019 electoral crisis, interim President Jeanine Áñez oversaw 2020 elections won by Luis Arce. Subsequent arrests of Áñez and officials, alongside allegations of judicial politicization and human rights concerns, prompted international scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss Bolivia’s political developments, judicial processes, and human rights challenges post-2019 crisis.

stances.stance:
EPP fully supports the issue's condemnation of arbitrary detentions and politically motivated prosecutions, perfectly aligning with EPP’s longstanding commitment to judicial independence and human rights.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on Bolivia’s constitutional legitimacy during the 2019 transition, reflecting EPP’s unwavering prioritization of democratic processes and rule of law.  
EPP unequivocally supports the demand to halt judicial persecution of opposition figures, recognizing this as critical to restoring institutional credibility and societal reconciliation in Bolivia.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of GSP+ conditionality to incentivize judicial reforms, ensuring trade benefits align with EPP’s vision of rights-based international partnerships.  
EPP commends the call to address Bolivia’s multi-ethnic identity through inclusive governance, resonating with EPP’s manifesto principles on pluralism and equality.

SD rejects the issue's characterization of judicial persecution, entirely disapproveing with S&D's emphasis on Bolivia's post-2020 electoral normalization and constitutional processes.  
SD opposes the amnesty provisions critique as overlooking critical aspects of Bolivia's reconciliation efforts following S&D-endorsed dialogue frameworks.  
The proposal fails to address SD's core principle that political stability requires respecting Bolivia's autonomous institutional developments since Morales' resignation.  
SD deems the terrorism law revisions inconsistent with their stance prioritizing domestic judicial sovereignty over external prescriptions.  
The issue's focus on Morales-era fund investigations contradicts SD's call for forward-looking societal healing through current constitutional mechanisms.

ECR completely supports the issue’s unequivocal defense of constitutional legitimacy, perfectly aligning with their commitment to upholding lawful transitions of power following President Morales’ resignation.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the condemnation of politically motivated prosecutions, reflecting their core principle that judicial independence must transcend partisan agendas.  
ECR completely supports the issue’s emphasis on the EU’s moral responsibility to protect political prisoners, given its role as guarantor of Bolivia’s 2019–2020 electoral process and post-crisis stabilization efforts.  
ECR fully supports leveraging EU economic and diplomatic engagement to demand immediate release of Jeanine Áñez and her ministers, consistent with their advocacy for human rights and rule of law in external relations.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the call to address Bolivia’s judicial corruption, viewing structural reforms as critical to fulfilling their manifesto pledge against authoritarian overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Bolivia’s political and judicial crisis following the 2019 presidential elections, which led to 35 deaths, 833 injuries, and arbitrary detentions amid widespread human rights violations. It condemned the arbitrary detention of former interim President Jeanine Áñez, two ministers, and others on charges of terrorism and sedition, noting her constitutional legitimacy as interim leader after Evo Morales’ resignation and the Plurinational Tribunal’s endorsement. The resolution denounced politically motivated prosecutions, lack of judicial independence, and structural corruption, highlighting concerns over Supreme Decree 4461 (February 2021), which granted amnesty to government allies, while opponents faced judicial persecution. It stressed the need for impartial justice, due process, and reforms to Bolivia’s judicial system, including revising vague anti-terrorism laws (Articles 123 and 133 of the Criminal Code) that risk violating human rights principles. The Parliament urged authorities to ensure medical care for detainees, reopen investigations into alleged misuse of $1.6 million in public funds under Morales, and address societal divisions through reconciliation. It acknowledged the EU’s role in supporting Bolivia’s 2020 elections and called for continued engagement via GSP+ negotiations, contingent on progress in democracy, rule of law, and human rights, while emphasizing the need for an independent ombudsperson and respect for Bolivia’s multi-ethnic identity.

title: Breach of the UN Convention of the Rights of the Child and the use of minors by the Moroccan authorities in the migratory crisis in Ceuta: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the breach of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the use of minors by the Moroccan authorities in the migratory crisis in Ceuta | RC-B9-0349/2021 | European Parliament
background: In May 2021, Morocco temporarily relaxed border controls, enabling thousands, including unaccompanied minors, to enter Spain’s Ceuta amid diplomatic tensions over Spain’s hospitalization of a Polisario Front leader. The EU and Morocco maintain migration cooperation agreements and a strategic partnership. The Parliament will discuss alleged breaches of child rights and migration instrumentalization in EU-Morocco relations.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the issue’s emphasis on safeguarding minors’ rights and EU territorial integrity, aligning with EPP’s principles of child protection and border security.  
EPP advises explicitly acknowledging Spain’s mishandling of the Polisario Front leader’s admission to ensure balanced diplomatic accountability in future crisis management.  
EPP proposes revising the issue’s title to reflect precise adherence to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, addressing procedural objections raised during parliamentary deliberations.  
EPP endorses leveraging the 2007 Spain-Morocco accord for minors’ repatriation while urging accelerated finalization of the EU-Morocco readmission agreement to prevent recurrence.  
EPP stresses the imperative of EU-Morocco dialogue to resolve tensions, noting that partnership stability outweighs short-term political maneuvers.

SD fundamentally sanctions the issue's condemnation of endangering minors as political instruments, perfectly aligning with S&D's foundational principle that child rights under the UN Convention must be inviolable regardless of diplomatic contexts.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for EU-wide solidarity in border protection, emphasizing Ceuta’s status as a shared external frontier requiring unified humanitarian responses as demonstrated by Spain’s actions.  
SD fundamentally sanctions leveraging bilateral agreements like the 2007 Spain-Morocco accord to ensure safe repatriation of unaccompanied minors, reflecting S&D’s long-standing advocacy for child-centric migration governance.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to address migration root causes through economic development, mirroring S&D’s Mediterranean Agenda priorities to reduce irregular flows via opportunity creation.  
SD fundamentally sanctions resolving EU-Morocco tensions through dialogue and UN-led Western Sahara negotiations, consistent with S&D’s commitment to conflict issue through multilateral frameworks.

RENEW supports the issue’s prioritization of child welfare under the UN Convention, aligning with RENEW’s focus on human rights-based migration governance.  
RENEW advises strengthening Article 4 by mandating independent third-party oversight of repatriation processes to ensure compliance with child protection standards.  
RENEW highlights the need to explicitly reference EU-funded educational reintegration programs in Morocco to address root migration causes, proposing an amendment to Paragraph 9.  
RENEW commends solidarity with Spain but urges adding provisions for EU-wide burden-sharing mechanisms to support frontline states with unaccompanied minors.  
RENEW suggests accelerating the EU-Morocco readmission agreement by setting a six-month negotiation deadline in the issue’s operational clauses.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue’s condemnation of Morocco’s instrumentalization of migration and minors, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to child rights under the UN Convention.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for prioritizing unaccompanied minors’ best interests, applauding Spain’s humanitarian relocation efforts as a model for EU solidarity.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue’s emphasis on resolving the Western Sahara conflict through UN-led self-determination, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for decolonization and international law.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for EU-Morocco dialogue rooted in mutual respect, rejecting any normalization of migration as a diplomatic bargaining tool.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the urgency of addressing migration’s root causes through development, mirroring their Green New Deal priorities for equitable regional stability.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to demand immediate implementation of zero-tolerance policies against illegal border crossings, totally disputeing with ECR's core principle that "fully securing our borders" must precede any humanitarian considerations.  
ECR opposes the issue's emphasis on bilateral repatriation agreements as insufficient, arguing this overlooks critical aspects like Morocco's demonstrated capacity to weaponize migration against EU territorial integrity.  
ECR condemns the issue's focus on addressing migration "root causes" through development aid as dangerously naive, inconsistent with ECR's documented position that economic incentives cannot replace border militarization.  
ECR disputes the issue's characterization of Ceuta's crisis as requiring emergency funding rather than permanent border infrastructure upgrades, directly contradicting ECR's 2021 border security manifesto commitments.  
ECR challenges the issue's diplomatic dialogue approach with Morocco as ineffective appeasement, demanding instead concrete sanctions against migration weaponization as outlined in ECR's "Hostile Actors Protocol."

ID rejects the issue's failure to address the EU's own culpability in creating migration incentives through lax border policies, directly conflicting with ID's demand for "no way" to illegal entry.  
ID opposes the humanitarian funding provisions as hypocritical given the issue's silence on the economic and social damage caused by uncontrolled immigration, which ID consistently condemns.  
ID completely opposes with the issue's call for dialogue with Morocco, insisting instead on immediate sanctions and frozen development funds until migration weaponization ceases.  
The proposal overlooks ID's principle of unilateral border defense by relying on bilateral agreements like the 2007 Spain-Morocco accord, which ID views as ineffective compared to direct EU action.  
ID condemns the issue's implicit endorsement of Spain's military border actions while historically prosecuting similar measures in Italy, exposing inconsistent standards that undermine EU territorial integrity.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s reliance on bilateral agreements that legitimize Morocco’s exploitation of migration as political blackmail, firmly disputeing with their stance against EU complicity in border violence.  
GUE_NGL opposes the failure to demand immediate suspension of EU-Morocco trade deals tied to Western Sahara resource plunder, overlooking critical aspects of economic justice central to their anti-colonial principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s silence on recognizing the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, a glaring contradiction with their decades-long advocacy for Western Sahara self-determination.  
GUE_NGL denounces the omission of activating human rights clauses in EU-Morocco agreements, which directly ignores their demands to hold authoritarian regimes accountable for endangering minors and civilians.  
GUE_NGL challenges the issue’s framing of “lawful repatriation” through existing accords, which they view as legitimizing Morocco’s state-sponsored child endangerment and EU border externalization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Morocco’s use of border control and migration, including the deliberate facilitation of an unprecedented surge of approximately 9,000 individuals—1,200 of whom were unaccompanied minors—into Spain’s Ceuta in May 2021, as a political tool amid diplomatic tensions linked to Spain’s hosting of Polisario Front leader Brahim Ghali and disputes over Western Sahara. It condemned endangering children and families, stressing the need to prioritize the best interests of minors under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and urged Spain and Morocco to cooperate on safe, lawful repatriation of children to families, leveraging existing bilateral agreements like the 2007 Spain-Morocco accord on unaccompanied minors. The resolution reaffirmed solidarity with Spain, emphasizing Ceuta’s status as an EU external border and commending Spain’s humanitarian response, while calling for emergency EU funding to support unaccompanied minors. It rejected actions undermining EU territorial integrity and urged Morocco to uphold migration cooperation commitments, including facilitating the return of 13,000 stranded Moroccan seasonal workers. The Parliament stressed the importance of resolving EU-Morocco tensions through dialogue, advancing a balanced partnership under the 2000 Association Agreement and the EU’s 2021 Mediterranean Agenda, and finalizing a long-pending EU-Morocco readmission agreement. It reiterated support for UN-led efforts to resolve the Western Sahara conflict and emphasized addressing root causes of migration through economic development and education in the region.

title: Global threats to abortion rights: the possible overturn of abortion rights in the US by the Supreme Court: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on global threats to abortion rights: the possible overturning of abortion rights in the US by the Supreme Court | B9-0299/2022 | European Parliament
background: The US Supreme Court’s leaked draft opinion in May 2022 signaling potential reversal of *Roe v. Wade*, alongside restrictive state laws and global abortion rights disparities, including EU member states with limited access, prompted concerns over transnational impacts. The Parliament will discuss implications for abortion rights and potential ripple effects on global gender equality frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's interference in US judicial independence, firmly conflicting with principles of sovereign state cooperation and mutual respect between democracies.  
EPP opposes the issue's call to integrate abortion rights into the EU Charter, asserting this violates subsidiarity and member states' exclusive competence on healthcare ethics.  
EPP condemns the issue's neglect of prenatal viability standards, highlighting contradictions in permitting abortions up to 24 weeks while neonatal medicine saves infants born at 22 weeks.  
EPP challenges the issue's singular focus on abortion access, advocating instead for policies to prevent unintended pregnancies through family support systems and paternal accountability measures.  
EPP disputes the characterization of abortion restrictions as human rights violations, emphasizing the paramount right to life from conception as foundational to European values.

SD strongly sanctions the issue's condemnation of U.S. state-level abortion bans like Texas SB8, aligning with SD's unwavering defense of bodily autonomy as a core human right.  
SD fundamentally supports integrating abortion rights into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, a critical step to match the issue's vision with enforceable EU legal standards.  
SD applauds the focus on marginalized groups impacted by abortion restrictions, directly advancing SD's intersectional approach to gender justice and healthcare equity.  
SD proposes specifying concrete EU funding mechanisms to offset potential U.S. cuts to global SRHR programs, enhancing the issue's operational impact.  
SD emphasizes the issue's vital linkage between abortion access and SDG 5 achievements, reflecting SD's manifesto commitment to systemic gender equality reforms.

RENEW strongly promotes the issue’s condemnation of U.S. efforts to overturn *Roe v. Wade*, aligning perfectly with RENEW’s longstanding commitment to universal sexual and reproductive health rights as non-negotiable freedoms.  
RENEW applauds the emphasis on disproportionate impacts for marginalized communities, which effectively advances RENEW’s priority of intersectional gender equality and healthcare equity.  
RENEW endorses the call for EU action to compensate U.S. funding gaps in global SRHR programs, urging immediate budgetary commitments to protect vulnerable populations worldwide.  
RENEW proposes enhancing Article 12 by specifying EU funding mechanisms, such as establishing a dedicated SRHR solidarity fund, to ensure sustained support for NGOs and healthcare providers.  
RENEW fully backs integrating abortion rights into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, recognizing this as critical to achieving Sustainable Development Goals on gender equality and health.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s condemnation of U.S. abortion restrictions and global anti-choice movements, aligning with their commitment to bodily autonomy and gender equality.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call to integrate abortion rights into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, reflecting their manifesto priorities for universal sexual and reproductive health rights (SRHR).  
GREEN_EFA endorses addressing systemic barriers such as third-party consent rules, proposing enhanced post-birth social support systems to complement abortion access reforms.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of EU action to counter ultraconservative networks like Ordo Iuris and Alliance Defending Freedom, as highlighted in the issue’s global threat analysis.  
GREEN_EFA urges accelerated Commission measures to enforce SRHR access across all member states, particularly condemning Poland’s pregnancy registries and Malta’s total abortion ban.

ECR rejects the issue's characterization of abortion access as a fundamental human right, asserting that international law prioritizes the protection of unborn life under conventions like the UNCRC.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the EU's interference in U.S. judicial sovereignty, condemning the issue's attempt to "coerce democratic legislation" through political pressure on independent courts.  
ECR rejects the premise that maternal health requires abortion access, arguing that true women's rights involve state support for motherhood and adoption systems rather than "normalizing death."  
ECR opposes the integration of abortion into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, citing Article 2's affirmation of life as the foundational right incompatible with terminating "a child with a beating heart at 20 days."  
ECR condemns the issue's dismissal of prenatal science, emphasizing that modern embryology proves fetal viability early in pregnancy, making abortion "a biological denial of humanity."

ID rejects the issue's interference in US sovereignty, asserting that the EU lacks competence to dictate abortion policies to independent nations like the United States.  
ID opposes the characterization of abortion as a human right, emphasizing instead the primacy of the right to life as outlined in international conventions.  
ID condemns attempts to undermine national "conscience" clauses, citing Article 10(2) of the EU Charter protecting conscientious objection in healthcare practices.  
ID challenges the issue's global SRHR funding demands, arguing that EU resources should prioritize supporting European mothers facing unplanned pregnancies.  
ID dismisses the issue's demographic concerns as hypocritical while ignoring Europe's own declining birth rates and inadequate family support systems.

GUE_NGL strongly sanctions the issue’s condemnation of regressive abortion bans in the U.S. and EU states like Poland, aligning perfectly with their commitment to feminist mobilization against patriarchal control of women’s bodies.  
GUE_NGL endorses integrating abortion rights into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, as highlighted by Rodríguez Palop, to counter judicial attacks mirroring the U.S. Supreme Court’s erosion of *Roe v. Wade*.  
GUE_NGL proposes the issue explicitly address illegal institutional “conscience” objections in public healthcare systems, which force marginalized women into unsafe or costly private clinics.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for global solidarity with U.S. women, echoing Clare Daly’s emphasis on transnational support networks that proved vital in Ireland’s abortion rights victory.  
GUE_NGL urges enhanced EU funding for public sexual health services to eliminate economic barriers, reflecting Pereira’s evidence from Portugal where abortion access reduced procedures through education and contraception.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over global backsliding in women’s rights and sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), particularly condemning efforts to restrict abortion access in the U.S. and EU. It highlighted that 45% of abortions globally are unsafe, with 97% occurring in developing countries, and noted 121 million unintended pregnancies annually, over 60% ending in abortion. The resolution strongly opposed the potential overturning of *Roe v. Wade* by the U.S. Supreme Court, warning of a 21% rise in maternal deaths post-ban and disproportionate impacts on marginalized groups, including Black, Hispanic, Indigenous, low-income, and rural women. It condemned restrictive U.S. state laws like Texas’s SB 8 (banning abortion after six weeks) and trigger laws in 13 states, with 26 states likely to ban or restrict abortion if *Roe* falls. The resolution urged the U.S. to decriminalize abortion, repeal restrictive laws, ensure federal protections, and address barriers like third-party consent and mandatory waiting periods. It called on the EU and Member States to defend SRHR, compensate for potential U.S. funding cuts to global SRHR programs, integrate abortion rights into the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and support NGOs and healthcare providers. The text emphasized links between abortion access, gender equality, and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs 1, 3, 5), stressing that denying safe abortion violates human rights and perpetuates gender-based violence. It also highlighted positive reforms in Argentina, Mexico, Colombia, and others, while criticizing regressive measures in EU states like Poland and Malta. The resolution urged universal access to contraception, comprehensive sexuality education, and healthcare, condemning "conscience" clauses denying care and stressing data privacy risks for abortion seekers. Finally, it called for global solidarity to counteract anti-choice movements and ensure SRHR as fundamental rights.

title: Government crackdown on protests and citizens in Cuba: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the government crackdown on protests and citizens in Cuba | RC-B9-0436/2021 | European Parliament
background: In July 2021, widespread Cuban protests erupted over economic shortages, COVID-19 management, and systemic restrictions on freedoms, met with government detentions, alleged human rights violations, and internet disruptions. The EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement, active since 2017, frames institutional engagement. The Parliament will discuss Cuba's response to protests and citizen rights.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally promotes the issue's condemnation of Cuba's violent repression, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to defending fundamental freedoms against authoritarian regimes.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands to trigger the EU-Cuba PDCA suspension and Magnitsky sanctions, mirroring Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez's urgent call to penalize officials responsible for systemic rights violations.  
EPP fundamentally promotes immediate release of José Daniel Ferrer and all political prisoners, reflecting Helmut Geuking's insistence on ending Cuba's "daily human rights abuses" against dissidents.  
EPP perfectly aligns with denouncing Decree 35's censorship regime, which Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez highlighted as criminalizing digital dissent through orchestrated internet blackouts.  
EPP fundamentally promotes independent UN investigations into torture and forced labor, advancing EPP's priority of holding Cuba accountable for its 8,000+ unjust imprisonments documented in the issue.

SD rejects the issue's call for suspending the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement, fundamentally againsting with S&D's insistence on maintaining diplomatic engagement to address human rights concerns.  
SD opposes the proposed Magnitsky Act sanctions as inconsistent with S&D's principle that punitive measures disproportionately harm citizens already suffering under authoritarian governance.  
SD condemns the issue's selective focus on Cuba while ignoring systemic rights violations in Brazil, Colombia, and Chile, creating an unacceptable double standard in EU foreign policy.  
SD challenges the issue's embargo reinforcement as contradicting S&D's stance that economic isolation strengthens regime narratives of external siege rather than enabling democratic reform.  
SD rejects the issue's narrow approach for failing to address root causes like U.S. sanctions, which S&D argues perpetuate Cuba's humanitarian crisis and political repression.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to demand immediate lifting of the U.S. embargo, which directly contradicts their insistence on addressing external economic warfare against Cuban citizens.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the one-sided condemnation of Cuban authorities while omitting the U.S. blockade’s documented role in exacerbating shortages and humanitarian suffering cited in the protests.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with their anti-blockade stance, as 184 UN member states—including EU allies—recently condemned the embargo as a violation of international law.  
GREEN_EFA criticizes the proposed PDCA suspension for ignoring how the U.S. embargo obstructs Cuba’s pandemic response and economic reforms, a key concern raised in the July protests.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s silence on U.S. sanctions as incompatible with their principle of opposing all unilateral coercive measures that violate human rights.

ECR entirely upholds the issue's condemnation of Cuba's violent repression, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to defending democracy and fundamental freedoms globally.  
ECR perfectly aligns with demands for Magnitsky Act sanctions, emphasizing the urgent need to hold Cuban military leaders accountable for systemic torture documented as crimes against humanity.  
ECR entirely upholds immediate UN investigations into forced disappearances, reflecting their unwavering support for international justice mechanisms to address state-sponsored human rights violations.  
ECR strongly applauds the issue's focus on Decree 35 censorship laws, which directly advances their priority of combating authoritarian digital surveillance and safeguarding free expression.  
ECR entirely upholds leveraging the EU-Cuba PDCA suspension clause, aligning perfectly with their strategic approach to condition cooperation on verifiable democratic reforms and prisoner releases.

ID strongly advocates the issue’s condemnation of Cuba’s violent repression and systemic rights violations, aligning with ID’s commitment to political freedom and anti-authoritarian principles.  
ID approves the demand for Magnitsky Act sanctions and suspension of the EU-Cuba PDCA, recognizing these as necessary measures to counter state-sponsored oppression.  
ID proposes enhancing the issue by urging parallel EU self-assessment of COVID-era restrictions to ensure consistency with liberties defended in Cuba.  
ID emphasizes the imperative for uniform application of democratic values across all nations, including EU members, to strengthen credibility when addressing Cuban abuses.  
ID endorses the call for UN investigations and dialogue, viewing these as critical to addressing Cuba’s humanitarian crisis while advancing systemic reforms.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue as imperialist interference aligned with US regime change agendas against Cuba  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the call for PDCA suspension and Magnitsky sanctions that reinforce illegal US blockade impacts  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's omission of Trump/Biden sanctions denying Cuba access to COVID vaccines and medical supplies  
GUE_NGL denounces the issue's false "human rights" framing that whitewashes 60 years of US economic warfare violating UN Charter Article 2(4)  
GUE_NGL demands withdrawal of all EU measures exacerbating Cuba's humanitarian crisis caused by extraterritorial US sanctions

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the Cuban government’s violent repression of peaceful protests on 11 July 2021, which saw thousands demonstrating against shortages, COVID-19 mismanagement, and systemic human rights violations. It condemned the authorities’ use of extreme force, including deploying elite "Black Berets," arbitrary detentions of over 1,306 individuals (including 27 minors), and reports of torture, forced disappearances, and summary trials for crimes like "social pre-criminal dangerousness," which has led to 8,000 unjust imprisonments and 2,500 forced labor sentences. The resolution highlighted restrictive laws like Decree 35 and Resolution 105, which enable censorship, surveillance, and criminalization of dissent, and denounced internet shutdowns aimed at concealing rights abuses. It noted Cuba’s failure to uphold the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA), citing intensified repression instead of progress on human rights, and urged the EU to trigger the PDCA’s human rights clause to suspend the agreement and impose Magnitsky Act sanctions on responsible officials. The Parliament demanded the immediate release of political prisoners, including José Daniel Ferrer, and called for independent UN investigations, fair trials, and dialogue to address citizens’ demands for democracy, economic reform, and COVID-19 response. It further criticized Cuba’s exclusion of civil society from EU cooperation projects and urged support for human rights defenders, Sakharov Prize laureates, and access for international monitors.

ECR strongly approves the issue’s condemnation of Hong Kong’s press freedom erosion, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to democratic principles and media independence.  
ECR endorses halting the EU-China investment agreement until systemic human rights violations cease, reflecting ECR’s stance on accountability for authoritarian overreach.  
ECR proposes amending the issue to explicitly enforce the European Parliament’s 2019 recommendation to remove Chinese-made surveillance equipment from EU premises, addressing security risks.  
ECR applauds the call for Magnitsky sanctions against Carrie Lam and other officials, urging immediate action to match their 2023 manifesto priorities.  
ECR stands in solidarity with Hong Kong’s citizens, emphasizing that the issue advances their manifesto pledge to defend autonomy against coercive “one country, one system” impositions.

ID supports the issue's acknowledgment of Hong Kong's civil liberties but advises reframing confrontational language to prioritize EU-China diplomatic pragmatism.  
ID proposes amending the issue to explicitly emphasize European strategic autonomy, avoiding entanglement in US-China geopolitical competition.

title: Human rights and political situation in Cuba: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the human rights and political situation in Cuba | RC-B9-0341/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (2016) established frameworks for engagement amid Cuba's constitutional emphasis on socialism, documented human rights concerns, restrictive laws on expression, and international reports on political detentions. The Parliament will discuss Cuba's human rights situation and bilateral agreement implementation under Article 36 provisions.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the issue's condemnation of Cuba's systemic human rights violations, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to democratic principles and fundamental freedoms.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand to enforce PDCA human rights clauses, emphasizing the Cuban regime's flagrant failure to uphold dialogue commitments as documented in Articles 1-4.  
EPP unequivocally supports the call to suspend EU-Cuba cooperation until forced labor in medical missions ceases, reflecting their absolute rejection of practices deemed modern slavery by UN mechanisms.  
EPP fully backs the issue's insistence on legal reforms to repeal repressive statutes like Decree 349, which directly contravene international artistic freedom standards central to EPP's 2021 cultural rights agenda.  
EPP categorically affirms the urgency of releasing all political prisoners, particularly San Isidro Movement detainees, as a non-negotiable precondition for any future dialogue – a position consistent with their Sakharov Prize advocacy legacy.

SD rejects the issue's punitive isolation measures as entirely challengeing with SD's commitment to constructive engagement through the EU-Cuba PDCA.  
SD opposes conditioning cooperation on legal reforms as counterproductive to dialogue-based progress, contrary to SD's emphasis on incremental change through sustained diplomacy.  
SD highlights the issue's failure to acknowledge Cuba's pandemic-era economic vulnerabilities, overlooking SD's priority of providing critical humanitarian assistance to prevent social collapse.  
SD condemns the issue's alignment with U.S.-style embargo rhetoric as inconsistent with SD's rejection of extraterritorial coercive measures against sovereign states.  
SD criticizes the issue's singular focus on sanctions over dialogue mechanisms, disregarding SD's documented advocacy for EU mediation in civil society-government negotiations.

RENEW strongly approves the issue’s condemnation of systemic human rights violations in Cuba, aligning perfectly with RENEW's longstanding commitment to defending freedom of expression and democratic dissent globally.  
RENEW approves the demand for immediate release of political prisoners like Luis Manuel Otero Alcántara, as this effectively advances RENEW’s priority of protecting activists from authoritarian repression.  
RENEW proposes amending Clause 12 to include quarterly EU-led assessments of Cuba’s legal reforms, enhancing accountability without diluting the urgency of aligning with international standards.  
RENEW applauds the focus on suspending EU cooperation under the PDCA if rights abuses persist, mirroring RENEW’s manifesto pledge to condition partnerships on tangible human rights progress.  
RENEW endorses the issue’s exposure of forced labor practices, urging strict adherence to ILO conventions to eradicate state-sponsored exploitation.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's punitive approach as totally conflicting with their commitment to sustained diplomatic engagement through the EU-Cuba PDCA framework.  
GREEN_EFA opposes demands to suspend cooperation, arguing this undermines the 2016 agreement's role in fostering incremental reforms like the 2019 constitutional market recognition.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's dismissal of Cuba's reform trajectory, noting it overlooks the PDCA's institutional channels for addressing human rights concerns through dialogue.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the characterization of Cuba's legal changes as purely repressive, emphasizing their view that Decree 349 and constitutional amendments represent contested but necessary modernization steps.  
GREEN_EFA asserts that conditioning EU relations on immediate prisoner releases contradicts their strategy of leveraging the PDCA to encourage systemic change rather than isolation.

ECR totally advocates the issue's unflinching condemnation of Cuba’s political repression, perfectly aligning with ECR’s foundational principle of combating totalitarian regimes and defending liberty globally.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the demand to immediately release all political prisoners, particularly highlighting cases like Luis Manuel Otero Alcántara, which exemplify ECR’s unwavering focus on individual freedoms against state oppression.  
ECR fully supports the call to suspend EU-Cuba PDCA cooperation until Decree 370’s digital censorship and Penal Code provisions enabling mass arbitrary detention are irrevocably abolished.  
ECR endorses the issue’s condemnation of Cuba’s medical mission abuses as modern slavery, demanding strict enforcement of ILO standards to eradicate this systemic exploitation.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the demand to terminate EU funding to Cuban entities masquerading as civil society, ensuring financial flows exclusively support verified democratic actors.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's selective condemnation of Cuba as imperialist interference inconsistent with anti-blockade principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the human rights accusations for systematically ignoring the U.S. embargo's catastrophic impacts documented in 62 UN General Assembly votes.  
GUE_NGL denounces the issue's medical mission criticism as slander against Cuba's COVID solidarity brigades that aided Italy and 40+ nations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the PDCA conditionality demands as violating the EU's own 2016 normalization agreement requiring non-interventionist dialogue.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the political prisoner narrative as manufactured pretext to destabilize Cuba's sovereignty through hybrid warfare tactics.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Cuba’s systemic human rights violations, including arbitrary detentions, political repression, and restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, and association. It condemned the Cuban regime’s intensified crackdown on dissent, citing 199 documented cases of political prisoners (65 new cases in 2021) and over 1,018 repressive actions in April-May 2021, including 206 arbitrary detentions and 13 violent incidents. Specific laws like Decrees 349 and 370 were criticized for stifling artistic and online freedoms, while the Penal Code’s "state of danger" provisions were highlighted for imprisoning over 8,000 individuals without charges and subjecting 2,500 to forced labor. The resolution denounced Cuba’s failure to uphold commitments under the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA), noting no progress on human rights since its 2017 provisional application. It condemned the exploitation of medical workers in overseas missions, deemed modern slavery by UN experts, with 622 testimonies detailing inhumane conditions. The Parliament demanded immediate release of all political prisoners, including San Isidro Movement members like Luis Manuel Otero Alcántara and Maykel Castillo Pérez, and urged legal reforms to align with international human rights standards, including ILO Conventions 29 and 105. It called for repealing repressive laws, ensuring judicial independence, and inclusive dialogue with civil society. The EU was urged to enforce PDCA human rights clauses, suspend cooperation if violations persist, and ensure Cuban civil society’s inclusion in dialogues. The resolution also criticized the Cuban government for barring EU Parliament visits and harassing Sakharov Prize laureates, while demanding accountability for labor rights abuses and systemic repression.

title: Human rights protection and the EU external migration policy: REPORT on human rights protection and the EU external migration policy | A9-0060/2021 | European Parliament
background: Global migration driven by conflict, inequality, and climate change has intensified EU cooperation with third countries on border management and returns, amid reported human rights violations. The Parliament will discuss the alignment of EU external migration policies with international human rights obligations and their impact on migrant protection.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely challenges the issue's failure to prioritize border security mechanisms essential for maintaining EU territorial integrity.  
EPP rejects the proposal's imbalance in addressing migrant rights without corresponding obligations, directly contradicting our principle that orderly migration requires enforceable entry regulations.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of hybrid warfare tactics by third countries like Turkey, leaving frontline states vulnerable to weaponized migration flows.  
EPP condemns the text's neglect of practical reception capacity limits, as evidenced by recent overcrowding crises in Ceuta and Lampedusa requiring immediate containment measures.  
This framework dangerously undermines member states' sovereign duty to protect citizens by prioritizing abstract rights declarations over operational border control realities.

SD firmly sanctions the issue’s demand for independent monitoring mechanisms to investigate human rights violations at EU borders, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to ending Frontex’s opacity and ensuring accountability for pushbacks.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s rejection of migration-related conditionality on development aid, emphasizing that humanitarian principles must never be compromised for border control objectives.  
SD fully supports formalizing migration agreements through transparent, legally binding frameworks, condemning informal deals with autocratic regimes as incompatible with EU values.  
SD perfectly endorses the call for binding solidarity mechanisms among member states, rejecting the externalization of border management to third countries that enables human rights abuses.  
SD fully advocates for parliamentary oversight of EU Trust Funds and migration partnerships, demanding an end to opaque financing that undermines democratic accountability.

GREEN_EFA fully approves the issue’s condemnation of migration policy outsourcing, perfectly aligning with their commitment to dismantle partnerships enabling human rights abuses in third countries like Libya and Tunisia.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand to cease diverting development funds toward border militarization, emphasizing the issue’s call to decouple humanitarian aid from migration control agendas.  
GREEN_EFA fully approves establishing independent human rights monitoring for Frontex operations, mirroring their manifesto pledge to enforce accountability at EU borders.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on legal migration pathways, echoing their decades-long advocacy for refugee protection and safe entry mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA fully approves rejecting reactionary alliances that undermine human rights, reaffirming their principle that migration governance must prioritize dignity over deterrence.

ECR totally opposes with the issue's human rights framework by rejecting migration governance aligned with international refugee conventions and non-refoulement obligations.  
ECR opposes the call for transparent migration agreements with third countries, advocating instead for unilateral border enforcement measures like Italy's naval operations referenced in Article 4.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national sovereignty by condemning pushbacks that ECR members explicitly endorse as necessary for "protecting European nations' cultural-religious identity."  
ECR rejects gender-responsive migration pathways and 10% NDICI funding for displacement causes, prioritizing border militarization over addressing root factors driving migration.  
This issue's focus on NGO oversight and Frontex monitoring directly contradicts ECR's support for criminalizing "immigrationist NGO ships" and rapid migrant returns.

ID rejects the issue's human rights framework as completely doubting with border security priorities, citing increased Mediterranean arrivals (13,303 in 2021 vs 1,219 in 2019) as evidence of policy failure.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national sovereignty by condemning pushbacks, which ID considers legitimate self-defense against "violent intrusion" per Nicolaus Fest's door analogy.  
ID opposes conditioning development aid on migration control as incompatible with border reinforcement demands, particularly Marco Dreosto's call for physical barriers along Balkan routes.  
The issue's gender-responsive policies contradict ID's core principle of civilizational preservation, aligning with Jean-Lin Lacapelle's stance that 71% of French citizens reject multicultural demographic changes.  
ID condemns Frontex oversight mechanisms as attempts to "slander" border forces, instead advocating expanded detention centers outside EU territory for immediate repatriations as outlined by Dreosto.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about human rights violations against migrants, including pushbacks, arbitrary detention, and violence at EU external borders, emphasizing the need for compliance with international law, non-refoulement, and accountability for abuses. It called for formalizing migration cooperation with third countries through transparent, legally binding agreements instead of informal arrangements lacking oversight, and urged independent human rights impact assessments for all EU partnerships, particularly those involving border management and returns. The resolution stressed the disproportionate risks faced by women (48% of global refugees), children, and LGBTQ+ migrants, advocating gender-responsive policies and safe migration pathways. It highlighted the EU’s obligation to align migration governance with sustainable development goals, ensuring development aid and humanitarian assistance are not conditional on migration control, and allocating 10% of NDICI funding to address root causes of displacement. The Parliament demanded enhanced transparency in EU funding for third-country migration programs, robust monitoring of Frontex operations, and stronger parliamentary scrutiny of financial instruments like the EU Trust Funds. It urged increased resettlement pledges, support for refugee-hosting countries, and ratification of key UN conventions, while condemning the criminalization of migrants and those aiding them. The resolution underscored the need for a human rights-based approach across all EU external migration policies, including accountability mechanisms, access to justice for victims, and inclusive dialogue with civil society and migrant-led organizations.

title: Human rights situation in Kazakhstan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the human rights situation in Kazakhstan | RC-B9-0144/2021 | European Parliament
background: Kazakhstan's reported human rights deterioration included restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, and association; pressure on civil society; flawed 2021 parliamentary elections; anti-extremism laws targeting opposition; torture allegations; and obligations under the EU-Kazakhstan Enhanced Partnership Agreement. The Parliament will discuss Kazakhstan's human rights situation and compliance with international commitments.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely upholds the issue's condemnation of Kazakhstan's electoral shortcomings, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to democratic pluralism and international observation standards.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand to cease digital surveillance, reinforcing EPP's foundational principle of protecting fundamental freedoms in EU partner states.  
EPP absolutely upholds the call to criminalize domestic violence, mirroring EPP's 2021-2024 priority agenda on gender equality and victim protection frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with leveraging the Enhanced Partnership Agreement, reflecting EPP's strategic approach to conditioning economic cooperation on measurable human rights progress.  
EPP absolutely upholds the issue's focus on judicial reforms, echoing EPP's longstanding advocacy against politically motivated prosecutions and torture accountability mechanisms.

SD fully agrees the issue’s condemnation of Kazakhstan’s non-competitive elections and systemic repression of civil society, perfectly aligning with S&D’s unwavering commitment to democratic pluralism and freedom of assembly.  
SD highlights the embassy’s passive diplomacy as an enhancement opportunity, proposing intensified EU diplomatic pressure to enforce human rights conditionality under the Enhanced Partnership Agreement.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands to criminalize domestic violence and end digital surveillance, advancing S&D’s manifesto priorities on gender equality and privacy rights.  
SD underscores the urgency of granting refugee status to persecuted ethnic minorities like Murager Alimuly, reflecting S&D’s cross-border solidarity principles.  
SD applauds the linkage of EU aid to torture accountability and anti-corruption reforms, urging strict application of the Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime to deter abuses.

GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the issue's systemic condemnation of Kazakhstan's authoritarian regression, perfectly aligning with their foundational principles of defending civil liberties and transnational justice. The documented persecution of Democratic Choice activists and weaponization of extremism charges directly mirrors their 2021 manifesto against securitized oppression.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the explicit linkage between EU partnership upgrades and human rights conditionality, echoing Heidi Hautala's demand to activate the Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against officials orchestrating election fraud and journalist harassment.  

GREEN_EFA highlights Niklas Nienaß's corroborated testimony about post-dialogue imprisonments as irrefutable justification for the issue's digital surveillance bans and immediate release of all 26 named political prisoners.  

GREEN_EFA acknowledges Tatjana Ždanoka's call for EU self-reflection on member-state democratic flaws but asserts this amplifies rather than negates the urgency to challenge Kazakhstan's torture epidemic and 112 religious persecution cases through binding accountability mechanisms.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's intersectional protections for LGBTI communities and domestic violence survivors, demanding accelerated ratification of Istanbul Convention benchmarks alongside refugee status for Murager Alimuly.

ECR strongly promotes the issue’s focus on electoral integrity and fundamental freedoms, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to democratic accountability and rule of law in OSCE partner states.  
ECR approves the condemnation of politically motivated prosecutions, urging enhanced OSCE-led monitoring of Kazakhstan’s legal reforms to ensure genuine implementation without opposing the issue’s core demands.  
ECR applauds the emphasis on protecting religious minorities, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of promoting freedom of belief through structured dialogue within the OSCE framework.  
ECR endorses leveraging the EU-Kazakhstan Enhanced Partnership Agreement to incentivize human rights progress, matching ECR’s manifesto goals for conditionality in foreign policy.  
ECR proposes strengthening collaboration with Kazakh civil society through dedicated EU funding streams to complement the issue’s call for ending harassment of NGOs.

ID conditionally approves the issue's mention of ethnic minority protections but requests revisions to remove references influenced by discredited lobbyist figures such as Äblyazov, whose criminal convictions in multiple jurisdictions completely disapprove with ID's emphasis on legal accountability.  
ID rejects the characterization of Kazakhstan's elections as non-compliant, noting this overlooks critical aspects such as the 200 German businesses operating there and 180,000 ethnic Germans in Kazakhstan – realities inconsistent with claims of systemic repression.  
The proposal fails to address ID's principle of non-interference in sovereign states' development paths, particularly regarding anti-extremism laws that align with EU-style security frameworks.  
ID opposes the sanctions consideration under the Global Human Rights Regime, arguing this disregards Kazakhstan's abolition of the death penalty and COVID-19 cooperation through 8,000 kg WHO aid deliveries.  
 While condemning torture universally, ID maintains the issue's corruption ranking (94th CPI) inappropriately singles out Kazakhstan despite similar scores among EU partner states like Mexico (124th) and Ukraine (117th).

resolution: The European Parliament raised serious concerns over Kazakhstan’s deteriorating human rights situation, including crackdowns on civil society, restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, and association, and systemic misuse of anti-extremism laws to persecute opposition movements like the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan and Koshe Partiyasy, with 26 named political prisoners and 99 politically motivated criminal cases under "extremism" charges since October 2020. It condemned the January 2021 parliamentary elections for failing to meet international standards due to lack of political pluralism, internet censorship, detention of 350 peaceful protesters, and obstruction of independent observers. The resolution highlighted widespread torture (200 annual cases reported), harassment of journalists (38 criminal cases in 2020), and discrimination against women, LGBTI individuals, and religious minorities (112 convictions for religious freedom violations in 2020). It urged Kazakhstan to release political prisoners, reform electoral laws, cease digital surveillance, criminalize domestic violence, and protect ethnic minorities fleeing persecution, including granting refugee status to Murager Alimuly and Kaisha Akankyzy. The Parliament welcomed Kazakhstan’s abolition of the death penalty but called for accountability for torture and corruption (ranked 94th on the 2020 Corruption Perceptions Index). It urged the EU to leverage the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to condition deeper ties on human rights progress, support civil society through funding, and consider targeted sanctions under the EU Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against officials responsible for abuses. COVID-19 aid, including 8,000 kg of WHO medical supplies, was noted, alongside concerns over pandemic-related repression.

title: Human rights situation in Turkey, notably the case of Selahattin Demirtas and other prisoners of conscience: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the human rights situation in Turkey, notably the case of Selahattin Demirtaş and other prisoners of conscience | RC-B9-0072/2021 | European Parliament
