ECR applauds the issue’s demand to repeal Article 144 of the Penal Code, which directly addresses legal mechanisms enabling persecution of religious groups.  
ECR underscores the urgency of leveraging EU-Algeria relations to safeguard freedom of belief, noting Christians’ disproportionate vulnerability under current laws.  
ECR condemns attempts to dilute scrutiny of Algeria’s rights record, stressing that excluding explicit references to persecuted Christians would betray universal human rights principles.

ID strongly approves the issue’s condemnation of Algeria’s judicial harassment against journalists like Khaled Drareni, aligning perfectly with ID’s longstanding commitment to defending press freedom and exposing authoritarian overreach.  
ID applauds the focus on arbitrary detentions since the Hirak protests, which mirrors ID’s advocacy against state suppression of democratic movements globally.  
ID proposes enhancing the issue’s scope to explicitly address Algeria’s anti-blasphemy laws and religious persecution, citing Yacine Mebarki’s case as emblematic of systemic discrimination against minorities.  
ID approves the call to leverage the EU-Algeria Association Agreement, urging stricter conditionality to combat Algeria’s criminalization of dissent under the guise of countering “fake news.”  
 While Dominique Bilde’s critique of Algeria’s religious hypocrisy aligns with the issue’s themes, ID emphasizes that any EU action must avoid conflating critiques of Islamist policies with broader anti-religious bias.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Algeria's deteriorating human rights situation, condemning the escalation of arbitrary arrests, detention, and judicial harassment targeting journalists, activists, trade unionists, and human rights defenders, particularly since the 2019 Hirak protests demanding democratic reforms. It highlighted the case of journalist Mohamed Khaled Drareni, sentenced to two years in prison for filming police violence, and noted over 200 arbitrary arrests between March and June 2020, with 91 prisoners of conscience documented by November 2020. The resolution criticized Algeria’s use of COVID-19 measures to restrict freedoms, including internet censorship and blocking six news websites, and condemned April 2020 Penal Code amendments (Law 20-06) criminalizing "fake news" with up to five-year sentences. It denounced the November 2020 constitutional referendum, which saw a 23.7% turnout and 66.8% approval, for consolidating military influence and failing to ensure inclusivity. The Parliament urged Algeria to release all political detainees, repeal repressive laws (notably Articles 75, 79, 95 bis, and 144 of the Penal Code), ensure judicial independence, and align legislation with international human rights standards, including the ICCPR and UNCAT. It expressed alarm at 41 femicides in 2020, restrictive laws on religious minorities, and Algeria’s decline to 146th in the 2020 World Press Freedom Index. The EU called for prioritizing human rights in bilateral relations, supporting civil society, and leveraging the EU-Algeria Association Agreement to uphold democratic principles, press freedom, and gender equality.

title: The deteriorating situation of human rights in Egypt, in particular the case of the activists of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR): JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the deteriorating situation of human rights in Egypt, in particular the case of the activists of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) | RC-B9-0426/2020 | European Parliament
background: Egypt's intensified restrictions on civil society, including arrests of EIPR activists and researchers since 2016, use of counter-terrorism laws to suppress dissent, and allegations of torture and unfair trials, alongside EU-Egypt cooperation frameworks, have drawn international scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss deteriorating human rights conditions and specific cases of activists and detainees in Egypt.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue’s demand to suspend arms exports to Egypt, viewing this as incompatible with maintaining counter-terrorism cooperation in the Mediterranean.  
EPP fully disputes with conditioning EU-Egypt relations on human rights reforms, prioritizing energy and water management partnerships as "areas of crucial importance."  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as Egypt’s role in regional stability, which EPP deems essential despite human rights concerns.  
EPP opposes imposing targeted sanctions on Egyptian officials, arguing diplomatic engagement is more effective than punitive measures.  
This issue is inconsistent with EPP’s emphasis on incremental reforms through dialogue rather than public condemnation of partner governments.

SD fundamentally supports the issue's condemnation of Egypt's systemic repression, perfectly aligning with SD's foundational commitment to global human rights advocacy and protection of civil society actors.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for immediate release of EIPR activists and Patrick Zaki, emphasizing this mirrors SD's 2023 manifesto pledge to defend academic freedom and shield human rights researchers from state persecution.  
SD fundamentally supports imposing EU sanctions on officials involved in torture and enforced disappearances, as this issue effectively advances SD's priority of using targeted measures to combat authoritarian impunity.  
SD perfectly supports conditioning all EU-Egypt cooperation on verifiable rights reforms, reflecting SD's longstanding stance that trade and security partnerships must never supersede fundamental freedoms.  
SD fundamentally supports the call for independent investigations into Giulio Regeni's murder, aligning with SD's institutional battle against extraterritorial human rights violations by security forces.

GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the issue’s demand for an EU arms embargo, aligning perfectly with their commitment to halt military exports enabling state repression.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to suspend budget support to Egypt, reflecting their principle that financial cooperation must be conditional on human rights progress.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the condemnation of Macron’s arms sales to Egypt, as this directly advances their manifesto priority to end complicity in authoritarian violence.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with demands to free all political prisoners, resonating with their decades-long advocacy for detained human rights defenders.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes prioritizing civil society in EU-Egypt relations, mirroring their unwavering stance that grassroots activism is vital to democratic reform.

ECR rejects the issue's call for harsh sanctions and comprehensive review of EU-Egypt relations, arguing it disregards Egypt's role in combating Islamist terrorism and regional stability.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to prioritize protection for Egypt's Christian communities facing violent persecution, a core ECR concern.  
ECR criticizes the motion's hypocrisy in condemning arms sales to Egypt while supporting leaders like Macron who engage in such transactions.  
ECR contends the issue undermines strategic counter-terrorism cooperation by ignoring security threats from radical groups in Egypt.  
ECR argues the proposal's punitive measures exceed proportionality, risking damage to EU-Egypt diplomatic and economic partnerships.

ID conditionally upholds the issue's call for prison decongestion amid COVID-19 but requests revision to acknowledge Egypt's legitimate counter-terrorism operations against groups like Muslim Brotherhood.  
ID requests amendments to Section 4 provisions on military trials to reflect Cairo's constitutional right to defend state stability from foreign-backed extremism.  
The proposal completely disputes with ID's position that EU security partnerships with Egypt must prioritize countering Turkish expansionism in Libya over human rights conditionality.  
ID rejects the issue's characterization of virginity testing cases as inconsistent with documented improvements in Coptic Christian rights under President Sisi's administration.  
The text fails to address Egypt's critical role in preventing Islamist takeover of Libya through direct military intervention against Turkish proxies, a strategic priority for European border security.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Egypt's deteriorating human rights situation, condemning systemic repression of civil society, journalists, activists, women, LGBTI individuals, and minorities through arbitrary arrests, torture, enforced disappearances, and misuse of counter-terrorism laws. It highlighted specific cases, including the November 2020 arrests of Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) activists Gasser Abdel Razek, Karim Ennarah, and Mohammad Basheer after meeting diplomats, their provisional release on bail, and the ongoing detention of researcher Patrick George Zaki, who faced torture and extended pre-trial detention despite health risks. The resolution noted alarming execution rates, with 110 executions in 2020 (66 since October 2020) and 39 individuals at imminent risk, often following unfair trials involving coerced confessions and torture, while 17 juveniles received death sentences since 2011. It criticized Egypt’s restrictive NGO and counter-terrorism laws, mass trials, military court use for civilians, and failure to address sexual violence, virginity testing, and FGM. The Parliament urged Egypt to release all arbitrarily detained activists, amend abusive legislation, ensure fair trials, decongest prisons amid COVID-19, and cooperate with Italy’s investigation into Giulio Regeni’s 2016 murder, implicating Egyptian security officials. It called on the EU to condition cooperation with Egypt on human rights progress, suspend arms exports facilitating repression, and impose targeted sanctions on officials responsible for violations. Emphasizing human rights as central to EU-Egypt relations, the resolution demanded transparency in EU financial support, prioritizing civil society, and mainstreaming human rights in bilateral talks, including at the next EU-Egypt Association Council.

title: The human rights situation in the Kingdom of Bahrain, in particular the cases of death row inmates and human rights defenders: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the human rights situation in the Kingdom of Bahrain, in particular the cases of death row inmates and human rights defenders | RC-B9-0190/2021 | European Parliament
background: Bahrain's post-2011 crackdown on dissent involved restrictions on freedoms, alleged torture, unfair trials, and increased death sentences, with 27 on death row by 2021. The EU-Bahrain partnership includes political and security cooperation. The Parliament will discuss Bahrain's human rights situation, focusing on death penalty cases and treatment of activists.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves the issue’s condemnation of torture-coerced confessions in the cases of Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Moosa, perfectly aligning with EPP’s unwavering commitment to fair trials and the absolute prohibition of inhumane interrogation practices.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for immediate death penalty moratoriums and independent investigations into systemic torture, reflecting EPP’s foundational principles of human dignity and rule of law.  
EPP fully supports the call for Bahrain to halt executions and ensure judicial independence, advancing EPP’s priority of global abolition of capital punishment.  
EPP unequivocally backs the issue’s emphasis on releasing political prisoners and restoring citizenship, resonating with EPP’s advocacy for dissenters’ rights and democratic freedoms.  
EPP applauds the focus on legal reforms to dismantle Bahrain’s repressive anti-terror laws, effectively advancing EPP’s strategic goal of aligning bilateral relations with human rights compliance.

SD absolutely accepts the issue's urgent call for a moratorium on executions and fair retrials for torture victims, perfectly aligning with SD's foundational commitment to abolishing the death penalty globally.  
SD perfectly aligns with the condemnation of Bahrain’s weaponized anti-terror laws against dissent, reflecting SD’s core principle that counterterrorism must never criminalize peaceful activism.  
SD strongly promotes halting EU exports of surveillance tools to Bahrain and proposes activating the new EU Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against documented violators, enhancing the issue’s enforcement mechanisms.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to integrate binding human rights clauses into all EU-Bahrain agreements, directly advancing the issue’s demand for rights-based bilateral engagement.  
SD absolutely accepts legal reforms ensuring judicial independence and UN mechanism cooperation, mirroring SD’s manifesto pledge to strengthen international accountability frameworks.

GREEN_EFA totally upholds the issue’s urgent call for an immediate moratorium on the death penalty in Bahrain, aligning perfectly with their unwavering opposition to capital punishment globally.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand to halt executions of Mohamed Ramadan and Hussein Ali Moosa, emphasizing the imperative of independent investigations into torture-tainted confessions as a core rule-of-law principle.  
GREEN_EFA unequivocally supports the condemnation of Bahrain’s systemic repression through arbitrary detention and citizenship revocation, mirroring their 2022 manifesto pledge to defend persecuted human rights defenders like Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja.  
GREEN_EFA champions the issue’s focus on ending labor exploitation under the Kafala system and advancing gender equality in Bahraini family law, reflecting their intersectional justice agenda.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the push for EU accountability in halting surveillance technology exports that enable Bahraini repression, a critical step toward fulfilling their commitment to ethical trade policies.

ECR fundamentally supports the issue's condemnation of Bahrain's use of torture-coerced confessions and extrajudicial executions, which aligns perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to due process and the absolute prohibition of cruel punishment.  
ECR perfectly aligns with demands for an immediate moratorium on the death penalty, particularly in cases like Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Moosa where judicial integrity was compromised by systematic abuse.  
ECR fully supports halting EU exports of surveillance technologies to Bahrain, recognizing their misuse in repressing dissent and violating privacy rights as detailed in the issue.  
ECR unequivocally backs the call to restore citizenship to over 400 arbitrarily denaturalized individuals, reflecting core principles of equality before the law and protection against statelessness.  
ECR strongly affirms the need to condition EU-Bahrain cooperation agreements on measurable progress in releasing political prisoners like Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and ending religious discrimination against Shia detainees.

ID slightly approves the issue’s condemnation of torture and arbitrary detention but requests revisions to acknowledge Bahrain’s regional leadership in religious freedom, such as the Awali cathedral project.  
ID highlights contradictions in the issue’s omission of Bahrain’s interfaith initiatives, which conflict with ID’s principle of balanced human rights evaluations that recognize progress alongside criticism.  
ID urges amendments to include commendations for Bahrain’s protection of Christian minorities, ensuring the issue reflects both challenges and advancements in religious coexistence.  
ID opposes the issue’s narrow focus on repression without contextualizing regional instability, advocating for language that encourages reform through dialogue rather than unilateral censure.  
ID requests the EU to revise its approach by integrating Bahrain’s interfaith achievements into human rights dialogues, aligning with ID’s emphasis on fostering mutual understanding in Gulf partnerships.

GUE_NGL fundamentally agrees the issue’s unequivocal condemnation of Bahrain’s systemic torture and extrajudicial executions, perfectly aligning with their unwavering stance against state violence and political repression.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the demand for immediate commutation of death sentences for Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Moosa, whose torture-coerced trials exemplify the regime’s brutality that the Left has consistently denounced.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally agrees the call to release Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and all political prisoners, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for imprisoned activists and opposition to authoritarian regimes.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with halting EU exports of surveillance technology to Bahrain, a critical measure to prevent complicity in repression, as demanded in their 2021 anti-militarization agenda.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally agrees the issue’s emphasis on judicial independence and citizenship restoration, mirroring their commitment to dismantling discriminatory systems like the Kafala labor exploitation framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over Bahrain’s deteriorating human rights situation, including a sharp rise in death sentences from 7 (2001–2010) to 50 (2011–2020), with 27 individuals currently on death row and 26 at imminent risk of execution. It condemned the extrajudicial executions of Ali al-Arab and Ahmed al-Malali in 2019, as well as the upheld death sentences for Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Moosa following trials marred by torture-coerced confessions, urging immediate commutation, fair retrials, and independent investigations. The resolution highlighted systematic repression of dissent, including arbitrary detention, torture, travel bans, and citizenship revocation for over 400 individuals (2018–2019), targeting activists like Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja (imprisoned for a decade) and Sheikh Ali Salman. It criticized Bahrain’s use of anti-terror laws to suppress freedoms, dissolution of political opposition groups like Al-Wefaq, and closure of independent media like Al Wasat. Poor prison conditions, denial of medical care, and COVID-19 risks were condemned, alongside discrimination against women in family law and labor exploitation under the Kafala system. The EU called for an immediate moratorium on the death penalty, release of all political prisoners, legal reforms to align with international standards, and meaningful engagement with UN human rights mechanisms. It urged the EU to mainstream human rights in bilateral relations, halt exports of surveillance technology aiding repression, and strengthen the EU-Bahrain Human Rights Dialogue to secure concrete reforms, including restoring citizenship, ensuring judicial independence, and protecting civil society.

title: The humanitarian situation in Mozambique: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the humanitarian situation in Mozambique | RC-B9-0300/2020 | European Parliament
background: Escalating Islamist insurgency in Mozambique's Cabo Delgado province since 2017 caused 1,500+ deaths, 250,000 displacements, and infrastructure destruction, compounded by extreme poverty, climate disasters, COVID-19 impacts, and resource exploitation tensions. The Parliament will discuss the humanitarian crisis, security challenges, and regional stability implications.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly promotes the issue’s emphasis on coordinated regional and international counter-terrorism efforts, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to multilateral security frameworks proven in the Sahel and Horn of Africa.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for Mozambique to address root causes of extremism through equitable resource distribution, reflecting EPP’s principle that natural wealth must combat poverty rather than fuel conflict.  
EPP firmly promotes the call to protect civil liberties and investigate security force abuses, advancing EPP’s unwavering stance on human rights as central to counterinsurgency strategies.  
EPP perfectly supports leveraging EU financial instruments like the €200 million post-cyclone aid package, mirroring EPP’s prioritization of humanitarian-development-security nexus approaches.  
EPP firmly promotes the issue’s linkage of responsible foreign investment to UN human rights standards, aligning with EPP’s advocacy for ethical resource extraction frameworks in conflict zones.

SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s emphasis on institutional reforms and anti-corruption measures, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to accountable governance and human rights protection in conflict zones.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for EU policy shifts toward demanding structural changes in Mozambique, advancing SD’s priority of addressing root causes like inequality and resource exploitation through equitable gas revenue distribution.  
SD strongly sanctions the issue’s dual focus on urgent humanitarian aid and parallel development programs, effectively advancing SD’s advocacy for regional cooperation with SADC and AU to stabilize Cabo Delgado.  
SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s insistence on investigating security force abuses, aligning with SD’s unwavering stance on justice for cases like Américo Sebastião’s disappearance to reinforce civil liberties.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s condemnation of irresponsible foreign investment practices, reflecting SD’s demand for EU-backed natural resource projects to adhere to UN human rights principles.

ID supports the issue’s recognition of Mozambique’s isolated counterterrorism efforts but advises explicitly condemning the Southern African Development Community’s (SADC) inaction, which has prolonged the conflict’s human costs.  
ID advises amending the humanitarian aid provisions to prioritize immediate protection for religious minorities, particularly Christians targeted in systematic attacks, as seen in Mocimboa da Praia and paralleled in Nigeria.  
ID supports investigating security force abuses but suggests conditioning EU funding on independent oversight to prevent militarized responses from exacerbating civilian vulnerabilities.  
ID endorses addressing root causes like unemployment but stresses that natural resource revenue reforms must directly benefit conflict zones like Cabo Delgado, where marginalized communities face dual exploitation by insurgents and extractive industries.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the escalating terrorism and humanitarian crisis in Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado province, where over 500 attacks by the Al-Shabaab group (affiliated with Islamic State) since 2017 have killed 1,500 people, displaced 250,000, and left 700,000 needing aid. The insurgents’ capture of strategic locations like Mocimboa da Praia—critical for LNG projects—and reliance on drug trafficking for financing highlight growing sophistication. Despite Mozambique’s military efforts, security forces face accusations of disproportionate violence, human rights abuses, and crackdowns on journalists, exacerbating instability. The crisis is compounded by extreme poverty (10 million in extreme poverty), COVID-19 (4,500 cases by September 2020), climate disasters (7.9 million needing humanitarian aid), and chronic underdevelopment (ranked 180th on HDI). The resolution urges Mozambique to investigate security force abuses, protect civil liberties, and address root causes like inequality, unemployment, and corruption, while ensuring equitable distribution of natural resource revenues (notably 5,000 billion cubic meters of gas reserves) to local development. It calls for enhanced EU support, including delivering pledged €200 million post-cyclone aid and €110 million COVID-19 relief, and regional cooperation with SADC and AU to counter terrorism and displacement. Emphasizing human rights-compliant military action, inclusive governance, and youth-focused education to curb radicalization, the resolution also stresses responsible foreign investment aligned with UN human rights principles and IMF debt relief (USD 309 million) to mitigate economic fallout.

title: Situation in Ethiopia: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Ethiopia | RC-B9-0383/2020 | European Parliament
background: Armed conflict erupted in Ethiopia's Tigray region in November 2020 between federal forces and regional authorities, following escalating political tensions over postponed elections, contested regional polls, and ethnic violence. The EU, a major aid provider, faced humanitarian access restrictions and regional destabilization risks. The Parliament will discuss the conflict's humanitarian, security, and human rights implications.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely advocates the issue's urgent ceasefire demands and humanitarian corridor provisions, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to civilian protection and international humanitarian law.  
EPP perfectly aligns with calls for independent atrocity investigations, emphasizing their manifesto principle that "accountability sustains peace" through rigorous judicial processes.  
EPP absolutely advocates the prioritization of African Union-led mediation, recognizing this as essential to advancing their strategic goal of conflict issue through regional ownership.  
EPP strongly affirms the condemnation of ethnic profiling and hate speech, mirroring their 2021 policy framework against identity-based violence in fragile states.  
EPP applauds the €4 million emergency aid allocation as effectively advancing their humanitarian diplomacy priorities while urging accelerated disbursement to Tigray's isolated populations.

SD fundamentally upholds the issue’s demand for an immediate ceasefire and unrestricted humanitarian access to Tigray, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to protecting civilians and upholding international humanitarian law.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for independent investigations into atrocities like the Mai-Kadra massacre, emphasizing accountability as critical to SD’s principles of justice and human rights.  
SD fundamentally upholds the emphasis on African Union-led mediation, recognizing this as essential to advancing regional stability and preventing broader destabilization in the Horn of Africa.  
SD fully supports the issue’s condemnation of ethnic profiling and hate speech, which directly aligns with SD’s priority of combating discrimination and fostering inclusive dialogue.  
SD perfectly aligns with the EU’s pledge of €4 million in emergency aid, underscoring the urgency of addressing displacement and safeguarding refugees, including Eritreans in Tigray camps.

ECR completely approves the issue's demand for immediate ceasefire and humanitarian corridors, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preventing civilian casualties in Ethiopia's Tigray region.  
ECR perfectly aligns with calls for African Union-led mediation, recognizing Ethiopia's historical significance and strategic role in maintaining Horn of Africa stability through dialogue.  
The issue effectively advances ECR's principle of sovereignty preservation by urging neighboring states to avoid intervention while supporting Sudan's refugee response efforts.  
ECR strongly sanctions the condemnation of ethnic profiling and war crimes investigations, echoing their insistence on accountability for atrocities like the Mai-Kadra massacre.  
This issue resonates with ECR's pragmatic diplomacy approach, emphasizing pressure on Addis Ababa to restore communications and protect Eritrean refugees as critical steps toward conflict issue.

ID partly advocates the ceasefire demand but requests explicit condemnation of Ethiopia’s constitutional violations enabling ethnic conflict.  
ID demands amendments to classify government actions as genocidal under international law, citing systematic ethnic targeting in Tigray.  
ID highlights the issue’s failure to address regional destabilization from disarming Tigrayan forces, which empowers Al-Shabaab.  
The proposal overlooks conditioning EU aid on verifiable cessation of ethnic profiling and mass surveillance.  
ID requests inclusion of Ethiopia’s constitutional secession rights to legitimize Tigray’s self-determination claims.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the escalating conflict in Ethiopia’s Tigray region, which has caused hundreds of civilian deaths, mass displacement, and severe human rights violations, including reports of indiscriminate killings, ethnic profiling, and potential war crimes such as the Mai-Kadra massacre. It condemned the armed conflict between the federal government and the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), urging an immediate ceasefire, unrestricted humanitarian access to Tigray—where 6 million people face isolation and 2 million required aid pre-conflict—and adherence to international law to prevent a worsening crisis, with over 38,500 refugees already fleeing to Sudan and projections of 200,000 more. The resolution called for independent investigations into atrocities, accountability for perpetrators, and an end to arbitrary arrests, surveillance, and hate speech exacerbating ethnic tensions. It emphasized support for African Union-led mediation, regional stability to prevent Horn of Africa destabilization, and the need for inclusive dialogue ahead of Ethiopia’s 2021 elections, ensuring freedom of expression and opposition participation. The EU pledged €4 million in emergency aid, stressed compliance with the Cotonou Agreement’s human rights obligations, and urged neighboring states to avoid intervention while supporting Sudan’s refugee response. It reiterated demands for Ethiopia to restore communications in Tigray, protect civilians and refugees—including 96,000 Eritreans in camps—and ensure humanitarian corridors, warning of broader regional consequences if the conflict persists.

title: Situation in Kazakhstan: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Kazakhstan | RC-B9-0065/2022 | European Parliament
background: In January 2022, Kazakhstan experienced nationwide protests triggered by fuel price hikes, escalating into clashes with security forces, mass detentions, and CSTO military intervention amid allegations of disproportionate state violence and human rights violations. The Parliament will discuss the government's response to protests and human rights concerns in Kazakhstan.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the issue's condemnation of disproportionate force and systemic human rights violations, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to democratic values and fundamental freedoms in EU partnerships.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for immediate release of political prisoners and independent investigations into atrocities, echoing calls to uphold international obligations regarding peaceful assembly and fair trials.  
EPP fully supports targeted sanctions under the Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime, recognizing the urgent need to hold accountable those responsible for torture and arbitrary detentions.  
EPP endorses the issue's emphasis on conditioning EU engagement through the Enhanced Partnership Agreement on concrete democratic reforms, mirroring concerns about Kazakhstan's geopolitical dependencies and the necessity for EU leadership in Central Asia.  
EPP strongly affirms the imperative to address media censorship and internet restrictions, aligning with demands for transparency and journalists' freedom to operate without interference during crises.

SD completely sanctions the issue’s condemnation of state violence and internet shutdowns, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to defending freedom of expression and peaceful assembly as inviolable rights.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for targeted sanctions under the Global Human Rights Regime, advancing SD’s priority of holding autocratic regimes accountable for systemic corruption and extrajudicial killings.  
SD completely sanctions the call for an OSCE-led independent investigation, reflecting SD’s longstanding advocacy for international oversight to address torture and arbitrary detention practices.  
SD perfectly aligns with linking EU engagement to democratic reforms, effectively advancing conditionality principles to end elite impunity and wealth inequality in Kazakhstan.  
SD completely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on judicial independence, mirroring SD’s demands to free political prisoners and end misuse of “terrorism” charges against dissent.

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue's condemnation of disproportionate force and systemic rights abuses, perfectly aligning with their commitment to democratic freedoms and accountability in post-Soviet states.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with demands for independent atrocity investigations and sanctions under the Global Human Rights Regime, echoing Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel’s emphasis on ending EU passivity through concrete actions.  
GREEN_EFA totally endorses the call to protect Kazakhstan’s sovereignty from foreign interference, converting Markéta Gregorová’s critique of EU inaction into a mandate for proactive diplomatic engagement against Russian geopolitical encroachment.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with Sergey Lagodinsky’s vision of crisis-driven reforms, supporting the issue’s insistence on legal alignment with international standards for assembly, media freedom, and pluralism.  
GREEN_EFA totally endorses Tatjana Ždanoka’s call for balanced dialogue by amplifying the issue’s demand to distinguish peaceful protesters from violent actors through rigorous, impartial judicial processes.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s condemnation of disproportionate lethal force and systemic human rights abuses, aligning with ECR’s commitment to accountability and democratic governance.  
ECR approves the demand for an independent international investigation into atrocities, proposing enhanced scrutiny of Russian military involvement to address geopolitical precedents.  
ECR emphasizes the need for EU-Kazakhstan energy cooperation to remain stable, suggesting sanctions under the Global Human Rights Regime avoid destabilizing critical energy supplies to Europe.  
ECR highlights Kazakhstan’s strategic role as a partner, advising humility in external assessments while endorsing reforms to combat corruption and media censorship.  
ECR urges prioritizing accountability for torture and impunity, aligning with ECR’s manifesto principles on rule of law and human rights.

ID partially promotes the issue's humanitarian aims but requests deleting references to "peaceful protests" in Article 1 pending independent verification, citing Krah's evidence of armed insurgents decapitating officers and burning government buildings.  

ID demands amendment of Clause 4 on "shoot to kill" orders to include context about constitutional obligations to counter armed rebellions, aligning with Mariani's caution against judging security responses without full operational intelligence.  

ID insists the issue address EU hypocrisy by adding a paragraph condemning Germany's COVID-era assembly restrictions (per Zimniok's police brutality examples) before lecturing Kazakhstan on protest management.  

ID requests removing the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan from "political prisoners" lists until judicial review confirms their status, noting Mariani's allegations of Mukhtar Ablyazov's billion-dollar theft financing unrest.  

ID requires inserting language in Section 9 about Kazakhstan's strategic neutrality needs between Russia/China and Europe, rejecting the issue's implicit demand for geopolitical realignment through sanctions.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s condemnation of state violence and demands for political reforms, aligning with their commitment to social justice and anti-authoritarian struggles.  
GUE_NGL advises amending the issue to explicitly address the role of Western and Russian corporations in resource exploitation, urging sanctions on firms complicit in elite corruption and labor exploitation.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening provisions on workers’ rights by mandating EU pressure for independent trade unions and legal protections against anti-strike measures.  
GUE_NGL highlights concern over the EU’s initial hesitancy to condemn Tokayev’s crackdown, stressing that energy partnerships must not override solidarity with grassroots movements.  
GUE_NGL endorses calls for media freedom but recommends adding measures to counter corporate censorship tied to state-aligned economic interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the violent crackdown on peaceful protests in Kazakhstan in January 2022, triggered by fuel price hikes and demands for political reform, which spread to over 60 cities and resulted in at least 225 deaths, including children and 19 law enforcement officers, with nearly 10,000 detained amid reports of torture, arbitrary arrests, and internet shutdowns. It condemned President Tokayev’s “shoot to kill” orders, disproportionate use of lethal force by security forces, and the misuse of “terrorism” charges to suppress dissent, while highlighting systemic human rights abuses, including political persecution of activists, journalists, and opposition groups like Koshe Partiyasy and Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan, with 13 activists sentenced to five years in prison. The resolution called for immediate release of political prisoners, an independent international investigation into atrocities, reforms to align laws with international standards on assembly, expression, and fair trials, and targeted EU sanctions under the Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime against officials responsible for violations. It urged Kazakhstan to address corruption, inequality, and media censorship, cooperate with UN and OSCE mechanisms, and ensure accountability for torture and impunity, while stressing that EU engagement under the Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement must be contingent on tangible democratic reforms and respect for human rights.

title: Situation in Lebanon: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Lebanon | RC-B9-0465/2021 | European Parliament
background: Lebanon faces a severe political, economic, and social crisis marked by institutional collapse, the 2020 Beirut port explosion, widespread corruption, and pandemic impacts, alongside hosting 1.5 million Syrian refugees and regional instability. The Parliament will discuss Lebanon’s multifaceted challenges and the EU’s engagement in supporting recovery and stability efforts.

stances.stance:
EPP fully supports the issue's demand for an independent international inquiry into the Beirut blast, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to judicial accountability and transparency in governance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's urgency for IMF-backed economic reforms, emphasizing Andrey Kovatchev's call for immediate EU action to prevent regional destabilization through financial assistance packages.  
EPP fully supports targeted sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277, mirroring Tom Vandenkendelaere's insistence on concrete measures against corrupt elites undermining Lebanon's sovereignty.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue's electoral integrity focus, directly implementing Paulo Rangel's emphasis on credible 2022 elections as a cornerstone for political renewal and EU observation missions.  
EPP fully supports the condemnation of Hezbollah's destabilizing role, reinforcing Λουκάς Φουρλάς' demand for EU-mediated political stability to counter external interference in line with UNSC issues.

SD totally approves the issue’s demand for an independent international inquiry into the Beirut port explosion, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to justice and accountability for systemic corruption.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for urgent IMF-backed reforms and anti-corruption measures, recognizing this as essential to restoring public trust and unlocking EU assistance for Lebanon’s economic recovery.  
SD totally approves the emphasis on credible 2022 elections with EU observation missions, reflecting SD’s priority of democratic renewal and inclusive governance to break political deadlock.  
SD strongly endorses targeted sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277, viewing this as critical to holding elites accountable and advancing the issue’s goal of dismantling entrenched corruption networks.  
SD totally approves sustained humanitarian aid for refugees and vulnerable populations, aligning with SD’s principles of solidarity and equitable crisis response amid Lebanon’s multidimensional poverty crisis.

GREEN_EFA completely agrees the issue’s demand for immediate application of targeted sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277, perfectly aligning with their anti-corruption agenda to hold elites accountable for stolen public funds.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for an independent international inquiry into the Beirut blast, advancing their decades-long commitment to transnational justice and institutional accountability.  
GREEN_EFA completely agrees conditioning EU assistance on electoral integrity and governance reforms, mirroring their manifesto principle of linking aid to democratic conditionality.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening asset recovery mechanisms to repatriate €24 billion in misappropriated funds to Lebanon, enhancing the issue’s anti-corruption framework.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with prioritizing energy sector reforms and social safety nets, reflecting their climate justice and poverty eradication priorities in multilateral engagements.

ECR strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on urgent humanitarian assistance, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to crisis response through Poland's airlift of 10 tons of powdered milk and medical supplies.  
ECR proposes enhancing Article 12 to prioritize immediate humanitarian corridors alongside structural reforms, ensuring medicine shortages and surgical anesthesia gaps receive equal attention to IMF restructuring.  
ECR applauds the call for sustained international aid matching their operational focus, having coordinated with Church-led networks to address 82% multidimensional poverty and refugee camp conditions.  
ECR endorses targeted sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277 as effectively advancing ECR's priority of combating corruption that blocks medical imports and electricity infrastructure repairs.  
ECR approves the issue's recognition of Syria/Palestine refugee pressures, urging specific EU funding mechanisms for host communities rather than centralized government channels.

ID conditionally upholds the issue's humanitarian framework but requests revisions to incorporate direct engagement with Syria's government, which they argue is essential for refugee repatriation and regional energy solutions.  
The proposal totally opposes with ID's position by maintaining sanctions on Syria, overlooking Zimniok's argument that lifting restrictions could enable oil transfers to alleviate Lebanon's fuel shortages.  
ID requests revisions to prioritize EU-mediated refugee returns to Syria, contrasting with the issue's focus on sustained aid without addressing repatriation pathways proposed in the debate.  
The issue fails to address ID's call for reclaiming Syrian oil fields from U.S. control, which Campomenosi indirectly endorsed through critiques of external interference in energy markets.  
ID opposes the issue's reliance on IMF restructuring without incorporating their proposal for alternative regional energy partnerships involving Syria and Iran-aligned actors.

GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the issue's endorsement of IMF-backed austerity measures, which directly conflict with our principle of opposing economic policies that exacerbate poverty and inequality.  
GUE_NGL opposes the imposition of external sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277, viewing this as imperialist interference inconsistent with our commitment to national self-determination.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of unconditional humanitarian solidarity by tying EU assistance to governance reforms that historically impose neoliberal conditionalities on vulnerable populations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to prioritize immediate debt cancellation and unconditional aid for Palestinian/Syrian refugees over political benchmarks that punish civilians.  
This framework perpetuates neocolonial power dynamics by conditioning reconstruction funds on compliance with EU geopolitical interests rather than grassroots needs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Lebanon’s multifaceted crisis, marked by political deadlock, economic collapse, and institutional failure exacerbated by the August 2020 Beirut port explosion that killed over 200 people, injured 6,500+, and caused $3.8-4.6 billion in damages. It condemned systemic corruption obstructing accountability for the blast, with political elites repeatedly blocking investigations, and urged an independent international inquiry. The resolution stressed the urgent need for reforms, including IMF-backed economic restructuring, anti-corruption measures, and transparent governance to unlock EU assistance, noting the EU has provided €55.5 million in 2021 humanitarian aid and €24 billion since 2011. It called for credible 2022 elections with EU support, including potential observation missions, and endorsed targeted sanctions under Council Decision 2021/1277 against individuals undermining democracy or misappropriating public funds. The Parliament highlighted extreme poverty (82% multidimensional poverty), food insecurity, and refugee crises, with 1.5 million Syrians and 207,700 Palestinians in Lebanon, urging sustained international aid. It criticized Hezbollah’s destabilizing role and external interference, reaffirmed support for UN resolutions on sovereignty and ceasefire, and demanded energy sector reforms, social safety nets, and equitable COVID-19 response. The resolution emphasized the 3RF reconstruction framework’s stalled progress due to political inertia and urged Lebanon’s new government to prioritize judicial independence, public service restoration, and accountability to avert further collapse.

title: Situation in Nicaragua: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Nicaragua | RC-B9-0400/2021/REV1 | European Parliament
background: Following Nicaragua's 2018 protest crackdown, escalating repression included arbitrary detentions, restrictive laws targeting opposition/media, disputed electoral reforms, and mass displacement. The EU previously imposed sanctions and noted deteriorating governance. The Parliament will discuss Nicaragua's human rights situation, electoral integrity concerns, and potential EU policy responses under existing agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely advocates the immediate expansion of EU sanctions targeting Daniel Ortega, Rosario Murillo, and their inner circle, as this aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to holding authoritarian regimes accountable for human rights violations.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's demand to activate the democratic clause in the EU-Central America Association Agreement, effectively advancing EPP's priority of conditioning international partnerships on verifiable democratic reforms.  
EPP absolutely advocates the call for electoral law revisions in strict accordance with OAS recommendations, recognizing this as essential to restoring legitimacy to Nicaragua's political processes.  
EPP fully supports the issue's emphasis on international accountability mechanisms for crimes against humanity, reflecting EPP's unwavering stance against impunity for state-sponsored violence.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the requirement for EU recognition of Nicaragua's elections only after verified implementation of impartial electoral bodies and unrestricted international observation, upholding EPP's foundational principles of democratic transparency.

SD fully approves the issue’s unequivocal condemnation of Nicaragua’s authoritarian repression, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to defending human rights and democratic pluralism globally.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for immediate release of political prisoners and electoral reforms, reflecting S&D’s core advocacy for transparent governance and opposition inclusivity.  
SD fully approves expanding EU sanctions against regime leaders, reinforcing S&D’s stance on accountability for systemic human rights violations.  
SD perfectly supports activating the democratic clause in the EU-Central America Agreement, consistent with S&D’s prioritization of conditioning partnerships on democratic adherence.  
SD fully approves international solidarity with Nicaraguan victims, advancing S&D’s principle of multilateral action against crimes against humanity.

GREEN_EFA completely approves the issue's demand for immediate release of political prisoners, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to human rights and democratic freedoms.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to expand EU sanctions against regime leaders, reflecting their prioritization of accountability for systemic repression and crimes against humanity.  
GREEN_EFA completely approves the activation of the democratic clause in the EU-Central America Association Agreement, advancing their strategic focus on leveraging trade tools to uphold democratic norms.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on international solidarity, echoing their longstanding advocacy for emergency visas and protection for Nicaraguan exiles fleeing persecution.  
GREEN_EFA completely approves the demand for corporate due diligence in supply chains, resonating with their policy framework linking trade to human rights compliance.

ECR fundamentally advocates the issue’s condemnation of the Ortega-Murillo regime’s authoritarian consolidation, perfectly aligning with their commitment to combating socialist-led totalitarian alliances in Latin America.  
ECR perfectly aligns with demands for expanded EU sanctions, emphasizing the urgent need to target Nicaragua’s leadership while highlighting Cuba’s role in sustaining regional authoritarian networks.  
ECR applauds the issue’s linkage of electoral reforms to international observation, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for transparent democratic processes free from foreign interference.  
ECR strongly endorses accountability mechanisms for crimes against humanity, urging rigorous enforcement of FATF measures to dismantle the regime’s financial lifelines.  
ECR emphasizes the issue’s exposure of Cuba’s destabilizing influence through the Foro de São Paulo, demanding parallel actions against Havana’s support for regional autocrats.

ID supports the issue’s condemnation of Nicaragua’s authoritarian regime and its demand for immediate release of political prisoners, aligning with ID’s stance against systemic human rights abuses.  
ID advises strengthening the issue’s accountability measures by explicitly urging EU member states to pursue legal action against Nicaraguan officials complicit in transnational crimes, such as Italy’s case against Alessio Casimirri, to reinforce anti-impunity efforts.  
ID endorses expanded EU sanctions targeting Ortega-Murillo regime leaders and financial networks, emphasizing the urgency of coordinated economic pressure to curb corruption and repression.  
ID proposes amending the issue to include a call for EU judicial cooperation with national authorities investigating crimes linked to the regime, such as Italy’s inquiry into Casimirri’s role in Aldo Moro’s assassination, to highlight historical attacks on democracy.  
ID stresses the need for the EU to condition electoral recognition on Nicaragua’s full adherence to OAS reforms, reflecting ID’s commitment to democratic integrity in alignment with the issue’s goals.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s condemnation of arbitrary detentions and systemic repression in Nicaragua, particularly demanding the immediate release of political prisoners and guarantees for physical integrity.  
GUE_NGL advises amending the issue to explicitly condemn human rights violations in allied states like Colombia and Honduras, ensuring parity in addressing authoritarian practices regionally.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the necessity of recognizing sovereign electoral outcomes even when politically inconvenient, urging alignment with non-intervention principles seen in Venezuela’s case.  
GUE_NGL proposes refining sanctions provisions to exclude broad economic measures that could harm Nicaraguan civilians, focusing solely on regime elites.  
GUE_NGL expresses concern over the issue’s geopolitical selectivity, which risks undermining its credibility as a neutral human rights instrument.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over Nicaragua's severe human rights deterioration since the 2018 crackdown on protests, citing over 130 arbitrary detentions, systemic repression, and abuses including torture, sexual violence, and denial of medical care to political prisoners. It condemned the Ortega-Murillo regime’s authoritarian drift, highlighted by restrictive laws like the Foreign Agents Law and Electoral Law 331 (passed 4 May 2021), which stifled opposition, dissolved two political parties without due process, and undermined electoral integrity ahead of the 7 November 2021 elections. The resolution noted the arrest of 21 opposition figures, including six presidential candidates, and over 108,000 Nicaraguans fleeing since 2018, 75% to Costa Rica. It demanded immediate release of all political prisoners, repeal of repressive laws, and inclusive electoral reforms aligned with OAS recommendations, stressing that EU recognition of elections hinges on restoring freedoms, impartial electoral bodies, and international observation. The Parliament urged expanded EU sanctions targeting regime leaders, support for civil society, and activation of the democratic clause in the EU-Central America Association Agreement. It called for accountability for crimes against humanity, independent investigations into 2018 violence, and FATF coordination to counter illicit financial activities linked to the regime, noting Nicaragua’s FATF blacklisting since 2020. The resolution emphasized international solidarity with victims and urged SICA and OAS to uphold regional democratic commitments.

title: Situation in Russia, the poisoning of Alexei Navalny: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Russia: the poisoning of Alexei Navalny | RC-B9-0280/2020 | European Parliament
background: The poisoning of Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny with Novichok, a prohibited nerve agent under the Chemical Weapons Convention, occurred during his activism against corruption and ahead of regional elections, amid documented prior attacks on dissidents. The Parliament will discuss the incident's context and Russia's compliance with international law.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely endorses the demand for an independent international investigation into Navalny's poisoning through OPCW and UN mechanisms, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to chemical weapons prohibition and accountability for state-sponsored attacks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for immediate EU sanctions targeting Kremlin-linked entities and individuals, effectively advancing EPP's priority of combating systemic corruption through asset freezes and Magnitsky-style human rights sanctions.  
EPP unequivocally supports the suspension of Nord Stream 2, recognizing this action as critical to severing strategic dependencies that fund Russia's military aggression and chemical weapons programs.  
EPP strongly advocates for isolating Russia internationally until compliance with democratic principles, mirroring their strategic focus on defending rule of law and supporting Russian civil society's democratic aspirations.  
EPP absolutely endorses reassessing EU-Russia relations to prioritize sanctions enforcement, reflecting EPP's unwavering stance against electoral manipulation and political repression documented in Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation reports.

SD totally advocates the issue’s condemnation of Navalny’s poisoning as a state-sponsored act, perfectly aligning with SD’s unwavering commitment to defending political dissent and exposing systemic corruption.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for Nord Stream 2’s suspension, recognizing it as a critical step to enforce accountability for Russia’s chemical weapons violations and strategic autonomy in EU policy.  
SD totally advocates the call for Magnitsky-style sanctions targeting Kremlin-linked individuals, advancing SD’s priority of combating impunity for human rights abuses and illicit financial flows.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s emphasis on reassessing EU-Russia relations, stressing that isolating authoritarian regimes aligns with SD’s foundational principles of rule-of-law conditionality.  
SD totally advocates amplifying support for Russian civil society and independent media, reflecting SD’s manifesto pledge to empower democratic actors against repressive regimes.

GREEN_EFA firmly advocates the demand for an independent international investigation into Navalny’s poisoning, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to accountability for chemical weapons violations and human rights abuses.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s call for Magnitsky-style sanctions, emphasizing the urgency of freezing assets tied to Putin’s corrupt elites as detailed by Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation.  
GREEN_EFA firmly advocates suspending Nord Stream 2, recognizing its critical role in halting fossil fuel dependency and isolating Russia’s regime for its repression of dissent and climate hypocrisy.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with prioritizing EU support for Russian civil society and independent media, echoing demands to shift strategic focus from corrupt elites to grassroots democratic movements.  
GREEN_EFA firmly advocates systemic sanctions against Russian-Belarusian collaboration in suppressing dissent, underscoring the need to target propagandists and enablers of authoritarian regimes.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's demand to halt Nord Stream 2, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to countering Russian energy coercion and hybrid threats.  
ECR approves the call for Magnitsky-style sanctions, emphasizing this effectively advances their priority of holding Kremlin-linked actors accountable for human rights abuses.  
ECR proposes enhancing monitoring of Russian military deployments near Belarus to reinforce the issue's regional security objectives, noting recent armored unit movements near Grodno.  
ECR strongly endorses linking EU-Russia policy reassessment to concrete support for Russian civil society, matching their manifesto principles on democratic solidarity.  
ECR highlights the issue's alignment with historical cases like Litvinenko and Skripal as critical to breaking cycles of impunity for state-sponsored assassinations.

ID rejects the issue's immediate attribution of guilt to Russian authorities as totally conflicting with ID's insistence on sovereign due process and evidentiary rigor.  
ID opposes the proposed sanctions regime, arguing it overlooks critical aspects such as the confirmed possession of Novichok by 20+ states and non-state actors since the 1990s.  
ID disputes the evidentiary basis for chemical weapons violations, citing contradictions between German lab findings and Russian physicians' conclusions documented in the debate.  
ID condemns the issue's anti-Russian rhetoric as inconsistent with diplomatic efforts to "bring Russia on board" (Krah) and avoid Cold War-style confrontations.  
ID rejects suspension of Nord Stream 2 as counterproductive to European energy interests, aligning with Mariani's warning against "nostalgics of the Cold War."

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong condemnation of the attempted assassination of Alexei Navalny through poisoning with the Novichok nerve agent, a chemical weapon developed and controlled by Russian military entities, as confirmed by German medical and military laboratories. It highlighted systemic repression in Russia, including over 300 political prisoners, a pattern of politically motivated killings (e.g., Boris Nemtsov, Sergei Skripal), and the targeting of dissent through harassment, impunity, and electoral manipulation, notably during the 2020 regional elections where Navalny’s "smart voting" strategy challenged pro-government candidates. The resolution demanded an independent international investigation involving the OPCW, UN, and EU, urging Russia to disclose its Novichok program and comply with the Chemical Weapons Convention. It called for EU sanctions, including asset freezes targeting corrupt individuals linked to Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation, a Magnitsky-style human rights mechanism, and the suspension of Nord Stream 2. The Parliament stressed the need to reassess EU-Russia relations, prioritizing support for Russian civil society, independent media, and democratic reforms, while isolating Russia internationally until it adheres to human rights, rule of law, and democratic principles enshrined in its constitution and international obligations.

title: Situation in Tunisia: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Tunisia | RC-B9-0523/2021 | European Parliament
background: In July 2021, Tunisia’s president invoked constitutional emergency powers to suspend parliament and consolidate authority amid COVID-19 impacts, economic stagnation, and institutional deadlock, including the absence of a Constitutional Court. The Parliament will discuss implications for democratic governance and EU-Tunisia relations under the 2014 Association Agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue’s demand to reinstate parliamentary functions and establish a Constitutional Court, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to institutional checks and balances.  
EPP approves the emphasis on inclusive national dialogue but proposes enhancing mediation mechanisms by explicitly mandating the National Dialogue Quartet’s coordination role to ensure broader legitimacy.  
EPP endorses conditioning EU assistance on democratic progress, urging clearer benchmarks in NDICI implementation to strengthen accountability frameworks while maintaining strong support for Tunisia’s development.  
EPP highlights the necessity of parallel economic reforms to address youth unemployment and brain drain, advising accelerated structural adjustments in labor laws to complement political restoration efforts.  
EPP commends the issue’s condemnation of military trials against civilians and gender equality safeguards, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of fundamental rights protection in partner countries.

SD absolutely approves the issue’s emphasis on restoring parliamentary functions and constitutional order, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to institutional checks on executive overreach as seen in President Saied’s decree-law consolidation.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for equitable gender reforms, applauding the recognition of Tunisia’s new female-led government as a critical step toward advancing SD’s priority of inclusive political representation.  
SD absolutely approves the urgent need for EU support to address Tunisia’s socio-economic fragility, emphasizing that COVID-19 relief and NDICI assistance must reinforce democratic accountability per the issue’s stipulations.  
SD perfectly supports the condemnation of military trials for civilians, aligning with SD’s longstanding advocacy for judicial independence and civilian oversight in transitional democracies.  
SD absolutely approves the issue’s demand for a Constitutional Court to enforce Article 80 safeguards, effectively advancing SD’s principle that emergency powers must not erode fundamental rights.

RENEW strongly endorses the issue’s call to reinstate parliamentary functions and restore constitutional order, aligning perfectly with RENEW’s commitment to democratic governance and rule of law.  
RENEW approves the linkage of EU financial assistance to measurable democratic progress, which effectively advances RENEW’s priority of incentivizing institutional accountability.  
RENEW emphasizes the urgency of safeguarding gender equality and judicial independence, urging enhanced EU monitoring to ensure reforms align with Tunisia’s 2014 Constitution.  
RENEW proposes amending the NDICI assistance clause to include quarterly benchmarks for releasing funds, ensuring transparency without opposing the aid principle.  
RENEW applauds the condemnation of military trials for civilians, noting its consistency with RENEW’s human rights agenda and regional stability priorities.

GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees the issue's demand to reinstate parliamentary functions and establish a Constitutional Court, aligning perfectly with its commitment to institutional checks on executive power as voiced by Salima Yenbou's emphasis on durable democratic structures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s linkage of EU financial support to democratic progress, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for conditionality in foreign aid to uphold constitutional rights and gender equality.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees the condemnation of military trials for civilians and prioritization of judicial independence, mirroring their unyielding defense of civil liberties highlighted in Jordi Solé’s critique of authoritarian overreach.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s recognition of Tunisia’s 2011 democratic legacy and the Nobel Prize-winning National Dialogue Quartet, reinforcing their view that civil society engagement is irreplaceable for sustainable reform.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees the call for equitable inheritance and family law reforms, seeing this as critical to advancing gender equality exemplified by the historic appointment of Tunisia’s first female Prime Minister.

ECR strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on reinstating parliamentary functions and inclusive dialogue, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to democratic governance and institutional accountability.  
ECR applauds the call for EU support contingent on democratic progress, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of tying financial aid to tangible reforms and anti-authoritarian safeguards.  
ECR proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly prioritizing proactive EU geopolitical engagement in Tunisia to counter foreign interference, ensuring migration and trade stability while maintaining democratic conditionality.  
ECR entirely approves safeguarding fundamental rights, including judicial independence and press freedom, as critical to restoring Tunisia’s constitutional order and preventing military overreach.  
ECR highlights the urgency of structural economic reforms to address youth unemployment and brain drain, urging accelerated EU-Tunisia cooperation to stabilize the Mediterranean region.

ID rejects the issue's condemnation of President Saied's consolidation of power, asserting his democratic legitimacy through overwhelming electoral mandate (72% vote) and sovereign right to combat corruption.  
ID opposes the characterization of constitutional suspensions as anti-democratic, emphasizing the necessity of temporary emergency measures to address systemic governance failures and Islamist-linked instability.  
ID entirely againsts with the issue's demands for parliamentary reinstatement, viewing the elected president's actions as legitimate popular mandate fulfillment against entrenched political corruption.  
ID rejects EU conditionality on aid tied to constitutional restoration, citing Tunisia's sovereign prerogative to determine its political reforms without external interference.  
ID opposes the issue's focus on institutional paralysis, highlighting President Saied's economic reforms (phosphate production revival) and gender-inclusive governance as tangible progress indicators.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's emphasis on inclusive dialogue and socio-economic reforms, aligning with their advocacy for equitable development and democratic renewal in Tunisia.  
GUE_NGL advises amplifying EU economic and social assistance beyond current commitments to address youth unemployment and public health crises, as outlined in the issue's COVID-19 relief provisions.  
GUE_NGL endorses the call to reinstate parliamentary functions while proposing explicit inclusion of trade unions like UGTT in constitutional reform processes to strengthen grassroots participation.  
GUE_NGL welcomes condemnation of military trials against civilians but urges adding specific protections for feminist organizations facing repression under emergency decrees.  
GUE_NGL cautions against overreliance on electoral timelines without parallel anti-corruption measures, suggesting amendments to link EU funding directly to transparency benchmarks in public institutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over President Kais Saied’s consolidation of power through Presidential Decree 2021-117, which indefinitely suspended Parliament, concentrated state authority in his hands, and undermined Tunisia’s 2014 Constitution by prioritizing decree-laws over constitutional rights. It highlighted the socio-economic crisis exacerbated by COVID-19, which caused high mortality rates, economic stagnation, youth unemployment (57.9% of Tunisia’s trade with the EU), and brain drain, urging structural reforms and inclusive dialogue to restore democracy. The resolution called for reinstating parliamentary functions, establishing a Constitutional Court to prevent misuse of emergency measures under Article 80, and safeguarding fundamental rights, including gender equality, press freedom, and judicial independence, while condemning military trials of civilians. It noted the EU’s substantial support, including over €2 billion in grants since 2011, €600 million in COVID-19 relief, and future assistance under the NDICI instrument, contingent on democratic progress. The Parliament urged Tunisia to reject foreign interference, uphold its constitutional order, and engage civil society, citing the National Dialogue Quartet’s role, while pressing for abolition of the death penalty and equitable reforms in inheritance, labor, and family laws. It emphasized that EU-Tunisia relations depend on shared democratic values and rule of law, urging swift action to address institutional paralysis and economic fragility.

title: Situation in Venezuela after the illegal election of the new National Assembly Presidency and Bureau (parliamentary coup): JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in Venezuela after the illegal election of the new National Assembly Presidency and Bureau (parliamentary coup) | RC-B9-0048/2020 | European Parliament
background: Venezuela's political crisis, marked by contested 2018 presidential elections, constitutional disputes over legislative leadership legitimacy, and deteriorating humanitarian conditions, intensified after January 2020 parliamentary session disruptions involving armed interference and competing claims to National Assembly presidency. The Parliament will discuss constitutional governance challenges and democratic processes in Venezuela amid escalating institutional instability.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely endorses the issue's recognition of Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's legitimate interim president, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to constitutional order and democratic transitions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for expanded targeted sanctions against Maduro regime officials, emphasizing that this approach upholds EPP's priority of holding human rights violators accountable without collective punishment.  
EPP absolutely endorses the condemnation of the 5 January parliamentary coup, effectively advancing EPP's defense of institutional integrity against authoritarian power grabs.  
EPP perfectly supports the demand to respect the National Assembly's constitutional role, mirroring EPP's foundational principle of separation of powers as a safeguard against tyranny.  
EPP absolutely endorses EU-led initiatives like the International Contact Group, aligning with EPP's strategic vision for multilateral diplomacy to resolve political crises.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s condemnation of Maduro’s parliamentary coup, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to defending democratic institutions and constitutional order in Venezuela.  
SD approves the call for expanded EU sanctions targeting regime officials responsible for human rights abuses, emphasizing the urgency of addressing Venezuela’s humanitarian catastrophe as highlighted by Nicola Danti’s data on poverty and medical shortages.  
SD proposes reinforcing international oversight mechanisms for future elections to ensure compliance with democratic standards, reflecting Isabel Santos’ demand to “devolver a palavra ao povo” through credible processes.  
SD endorses the issue’s recognition of Guaidó’s legitimacy under Article 233, noting Javi López’s emphasis on his constitutional re-election despite regime obstruction.  
SD urges the EU to prioritize pressure on external actors like Russia, whose support enables Maduro’s repression, as a critical enhancement to current sanctions frameworks.

ECR strongly agrees the issue's condemnation of the Maduro regime's parliamentary coup, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to defending constitutional order against authoritarian subversion.  

ECR proposes expanding targeted sanctions to explicitly include regime operatives in Spain and EU states who openly flaunt illicit wealth, amending the issue to mandate cross-border asset freezes.  

ECR highlights the urgency of investigating the regime's transnational corruption networks, particularly its alliances with Spanish political allies in government, which threaten European democratic integrity.  

ECR completely accepts the call for stricter EU coordination against Maduro’s narco-dictatorship, urging immediate enforcement of travel bans and financial restrictions on all regime collaborators.  

ECR applauds the issue’s recognition of Juan Guaidó’s legitimacy as critical to restoring Venezuela’s democracy, reflecting ECR’s unwavering support for constitutionally mandated leadership.

ID supports the issue’s condemnation of Maduro’s authoritarian tactics and reaffirmation of Juan Guaidó’s constitutional legitimacy, aligning with ID’s emphasis on democratic accountability.  
ID advises explicitly naming socialist ideology’s role in Venezuela’s collapse to address root causes, as the issue underemphasizes systemic left-wing authoritarianism.  
ID calls for EU measures to counter European far-left groups that glorify Maduro’s regime, proposing amendments to expand sanctions to include such networks.  
ID endorses targeted sanctions but urges stricter enforcement against regime financiers in Europe, including audits of Venezuelan state assets held in EU jurisdictions.  
ID stresses the need to link Venezuela’s crisis to broader warnings about socialist governance, ensuring EU policies preempt similar destabilization in Europe.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the political crisis in Venezuela, condemning the Maduro regime’s orchestrated parliamentary coup on 5 January 2020 to illegitimately replace Juan Guaidó as President of the National Assembly. It reaffirmed Guaidó’s legitimacy as interim president under Article 233 of the Venezuelan Constitution, citing his re-election by 100 of 167 parliamentarians in a constitutionally compliant session held under duress, and noted his recognition by over 50 countries, including 25 EU Member States. The resolution denounced the regime’s violent obstruction of parliamentary processes, including barring opposition lawmakers, blocking press access, and using force to disrupt Guaidó’s swearing-in on 7 January. It highlighted systemic human rights abuses, including harassment of 59 National Assembly members, 29 arbitrary detentions, and 27 forced exiles, and rejected the 2018 presidential elections as illegitimate. The Parliament urged EU Member States to recognize Guaidó, called for expanded targeted sanctions against individuals responsible for repression, and supported EU-led initiatives, such as the International Contact Group, to facilitate a peaceful democratic transition. It also demanded respect for the National Assembly’s constitutional role and requested a fact-finding mission to assess the crisis.

title: Situation of human rights and democracy in Nicaragua: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation of human rights and democracy in Nicaragua | RC-B9-0251/2019 | European Parliament
background: Nicaragua faced escalating human rights violations, including repression of dissent, arbitrary detentions, deaths, forced exile of critics, media suppression, expulsion of international human rights bodies, and stalled dialogue following 2018 protests. The Parliament will discuss the deterioration of democratic governance and human rights in Nicaragua.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's condemnation of systemic human rights abuses in Nicaragua, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to defending democratic values and protecting European citizens like Amaya Coppens from authoritarian regimes.  
EPP approves the call for targeted EU sanctions against Ortega-Murillo officials, emphasizing how this effectively advances EPP's priority of holding dictators accountable through Magnitsky-style measures while protecting vulnerable populations.  
EPP proposes enhancing provisions for exiled Nicaraguans by specifying EU assistance programs for the 80,000 forced into displacement, ensuring this humanitarian crisis receives dedicated funding streams in implementation.  
EPP applauds the demand for judicial reforms and Amnesty Law revisions as directly mirroring EPP's 2023 manifesto pledge to combat impunity through institutional accountability frameworks in partner nations.  
EPP insists on strict enforcement of the EU-Central America Agreement's democratic clause, noting how suspending Nicaragua aligns with EPP's consistent stance that trade privileges require adherence to rule-of-law conditionality.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s condemnation of systemic repression in Nicaragua, aligning with S&D’s unwavering commitment to human rights and democratic accountability.  
SD applauds the demand for targeted EU sanctions against Ortega’s regime, reflecting their manifesto pledge to combat impunity for state-sponsored violence.  
SD urges immediate electoral reforms and EU monitoring missions to restore democratic legitimacy, emphasizing S&D’s prioritization of free and fair elections.  
SD proposes maintaining diplomatic engagement to facilitate dialogue while applying pressure, ensuring pathways for peaceful issue without legitimizing abuses.  
SD endorses the call to reinstate exiled citizens and restore civil freedoms, directly advancing S&D’s advocacy for displaced populations and press freedom.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's condemnation of systemic repression in Nicaragua, aligning with their commitment to global human rights advocacy and protection of political prisoners.
